## 9. cliclick â€” Mouse/Keyboard Automation

### Available on This System âœ…
Location: `/opt/homebrew/bin/cliclick`

### Command Reference
```bash
# Click at coordinates
cliclick c:100,200

# Right-click
cliclick rc:100,200

# Double-click
cliclick dc:100,200

# Move mouse
cliclick m:100,200

# Type text
cliclick t:"Hello World"

# Press key
cliclick kp:return
cliclick kp:tab
cliclick kp:escape

# Key down/up (for modifiers)
cliclick kd:cmd ku:cmd

# Cmd+C (copy)
cliclick kd:cmd t:c ku:cmd

# Get current mouse position
cliclick p:.

# Drag from point to point
cliclick dd:100,200 du:300,400

# Wait between actions (milliseconds)
cliclick w:500

# Combined: click, wait, type
cliclick c:100,200 w:500 t:"Hello"

# Relative movement
cliclick m:+50,+0  # Move 50px right

# Verbose mode (print actions)
cliclick -m verbose c:100,200

# Test mode (print but don't execute)
cliclick -m test c:100,200

# Read commands from file
cliclick -f commands.txt
```

### What It Enables
- Control ANY app regardless of accessibility API support
- Automate apps with no scripting interface
- Fill forms, click buttons, navigate menus
- Combined with screenshots â†’ visual automation

### What It Can't Do
- Needs to know exact coordinates (fragile)
- Can't read screen content (combine with `screencapture`)
- Interferes with user activity (moves their mouse)
- No element detection â€” pure coordinates
- Screen resolution/scaling affects coordinates

### Security/Permissions
- Requires **Accessibility** permission for the calling app
- No other special permissions

### AI Reliability: â­â­ (Low for coordinates) / â­â­â­â­ (High for typing/keys)
Typing and key presses are reliable. Coordinate-based clicking is fragile. Best combined with Accessibility API to find element positions first:

```applescript
-- Get position of a button, then click it with cliclick
tell application "System Events"
    tell process "AppName"
        set {x, y} to position of button "OK" of window 1
        set {w, h} to size of button "OK" of window 1
    end tell
end tell
-- Then: cliclick c:{x + w/2},{y + h/2}
```

---

## 10. Bonus: JXA (JavaScript for Automation)

### Why JXA Matters for AI
JXA is JavaScript that can do everything AppleScript does. Since AI models are far better at JavaScript than AppleScript, this is a huge win.

```bash
# Run JXA from command line
osascript -l JavaScript -e '
var se = Application("System Events");
var procs = se.processes.whose({backgroundOnly: false})();
procs.slice(0,5).map(p => p.name());
'
```

### Verified Working
```bash
# Returns: ["System Settings", "Google Chrome", "Telegram", "Wispr Flow", "Claude"]
```

### Advantages Over AppleScript
- JavaScript syntax (AI generates this much more reliably)
- Better string manipulation, JSON support
- Can use `$.NSString`, `$.NSURL` etc. for ObjC bridge
- Proper error handling with try/catch

### AI Reliability: â­â­â­â­â­ (Very High)
AI models are extremely good at JavaScript. JXA should be the **preferred** scripting approach over AppleScript.

memory/projects/macos-cli-swift-framewor:
# macOS CLI Swift Framework â€” Research Findings

**Purpose:** Enable an AI agent to rapidly generate Swift CLI tools that interface with native macOS frameworks and apps.  
**Researched:** 2025-07-14  
**System:** macOS 26.0, Swift 6.2.3, Apple Silicon (arm64), Command Line Tools installed

---

## 1. Swift Package Manager Setup

### Minimal Package.swift Template
```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "mycli",
    platforms: [.macOS(.v13)],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(name: "mycli")
    ]
)
```

### With swift-argument-parser
```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "mycli",
    platforms: [.macOS(.v13)],
    dependencies: [
        .package(url: "https://github.com/apple/swift-argument-parser", from: "1.3.0"),
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "mycli",
            dependencies: [
                .product(name: "ArgumentParser", package: "swift-argument-parser"),
            ]
        ),
    ]
)
```

### Directory Structure
```
mycli/
â”œâ”€â”€ Package.swift
â””â”€â”€ Sources/
    â””â”€â”€ mycli/
        â””â”€â”€ main.swift   (or MyCLI.swift with @main)
```

**Create with:** `swift package init --type executable`

---

## 2. Build & Run Performance

| Operation | Time | Notes |
|-----------|------|-------|
| `swift package init` | **0.15s** | Instant project scaffold |
| `swiftc single-file.swift` | **0.3s** | Single file, no SPM overhead |
| `swift build` (clean, no deps) | **14s** | First build of minimal project |
| `swift build` (clean, with ArgumentParser) | **26s** | First build fetches + compiles dependency |
| `swift build` (incremental) | **1.5s** | After modifying one file |
| `swift run` | Same as build + run | |

### Key Insight: Single-File Mode is FAST
For simple tools, skip SPM entirely:
```bash
swiftc tool.swift -o tool && ./tool    # 0.3 seconds!
```

This is **the recommended approach for AI-generated CLIs** â€” no Package.swift needed, no dependency resolution, compiles in under a second.

For tools needing ArgumentParser or other deps, use SPM but expect ~26s first build (1.5s incremental).

---

## 3. Framework Accessibility from CLI Swift

### âœ… Fully Working from CLI (Tested)

| Framework | Import | Works? | Notes |
|-----------|--------|--------|-------|
| **EventKit** | `import EventKit` | âœ… | Calendars, Reminders. Full access. |
| **Contacts** | `import Contacts` | âœ… | Full CNContact access, enumeration works |
| **CoreLocation** | `import CoreLocation` | âœ… | Compiles & runs. Needs RunLoop for callbacks |
| **CoreBluetooth** | `import CoreBluetooth` | âœ… | Compiles. Needs RunLoop for delegate callbacks |
| **Photos** | `import Photos` | âœ… | Compiles. Needs TCC permission |
| **AVFoundation** | `import AVFoundation` | âœ… | Works for asset handling. AVAudioSession is iOS-only |
| **ScriptingBridge** | `import ScriptingBridge` | âœ… | Control scriptable apps (Notes, Safari, Music) |
| **Foundation** | `import Foundation` | âœ… | NSAppleScript, FileManager, URLSession, etc. |
| **SQLite3** | `import SQLite3` | âœ… | Direct database access (Notes, Messages, etc.) |

### âš ï¸ Require RunLoop
These frameworks use delegate callbacks and need `RunLoop.main.run()`:
- **CoreLocation** â€” location updates come via delegate
- **CoreBluetooth** â€” device discovery via delegate
- **Photos** â€” authorization callback is async

**Pattern for RunLoop-dependent frameworks:**
```swift
import Foundation

// ... setup delegates ...

// Option 1: Run for fixed duration
RunLoop.main.run(until: Date(timeIntervalSinceNow: 5))

// Option 2: Use DispatchSemaphore for one-shot operations
let semaphore = DispatchSemaphore(value: 0)
someAsyncCall { result in
    // process result
    semaphore.signal()
}
semaphore.wait()

// Option 3: Use async/await (Swift 5.5+)
// Wrap in @main struct with static func main() async
```

### âŒ Not Available / Not Useful from CLI
- **UIKit** â€” iOS only
- **SwiftUI** â€” needs an app lifecycle
- **AVAudioSession** â€” iOS only (use AVFoundation for macOS audio)
- **HealthKit** â€” iOS/watchOS only

---

## 4. Accessing App-Specific Data

### Reminders (EventKit)
```swift
import EventKit
import Foundation

let store = EKEventStore()
let sem = DispatchSemaphore(value: 0)

store.requestFullAccessToReminders { granted, error in
    if granted {
        let calendars = store.calendars(for: .reminder)
        let predicate = store.predicateForIncompleteReminders(
            withDueDateStarting: nil, ending: nil, calendars: nil
        )
        store.fetchReminders(matching: predicate) { reminders in
            for r in reminders ?? [] {
                print(r.title ?? "untitled")
            }
            sem.signal()
        }
    } else {
        sem.signal()
    }
}
sem.wait()
```
**TCC:** First run prompts for Reminders access. Subsequent runs work silently.

### Calendars (EventKit)
```swift
let store = EKEventStore()
store.requestFullAccessToEvents { granted, _ in
    if granted {
        let cals = store.calendars(for: .event)
        let pred = store.predicateForEvents(
            withStart: Date(), 
            end: Date().addingTimeInterval(86400), 
            calendars: nil
        )
        let events = store.events(matching: pred)
        for e in events {
            print("\(e.title ?? "") - \(e.startDate!)")
        }
    }
}
```

### Contacts (CNContact)
```swift
import Contacts

let store = CNContactStore()
let keys = [CNContactGivenNameKey, CNContactFamilyNameKey, 
            CNContactEmailAddressesKey] as [CNKeyDescriptor]
let request = CNContactFetchRequest(keysToFetch: keys)
try store.enumerateContacts(with: request) { contact, _ in
    print("\(contact.givenName) \(contact.familyName)")
}
```
**TCC:** Prompts for Contacts access on first run.

### Notes.app â€” Three Approaches

#### Approach 1: NSAppleScript (Recommended for simple reads)
```swift
import Foundation

let script = NSAppleScript(source: """
    tell application "Notes"
        set noteNames to name of every note
        return noteNames
    end tell
""")!
var error: NSDictionary?
let result = script.executeAndReturnError(&error)
// Process result...
```
**Pros:** No direct DB access, respects app API, can create/modify notes  
**Cons:** Launches Notes.app, slower, limited query capability  
**TCC:** May prompt for Automation permission

#### Approach 2: SQLite Direct (Read-only, powerful)
```swift
import SQLite3
// DB location:
// ~/Library/Group Containers/group.com.apple.notes/NoteStore.sqlite
```
**Schema tables:** `ZICCLOUDSYNCINGOBJECT` (main note data), `ZICNOTEDATA` (note body as protobuf/gzipped HTML)  
**Pros:** Fast, no app launch, full query power  
**Cons:** Read-only (modifying breaks iCloud sync), schema undocumented, body is compressed protobuf  
**TCC:** Needs Full Disk Access for the file path

#### Approach 3: ScriptingBridge (Type-safe AppleScript)
```swift
import ScriptingBridge
let app: AnyObject = SBApplication(bundleIdentifier: "com.apple.Notes")!
```
**Pros:** Swift-native, type-safe  
**Cons:** Requires generating bridge headers, complex setup

**Recommendation:** Use AppleScript via `osascript` or NSAppleScript for Notes. SQLite only for read-heavy search operations.

### Messages/iMessage
- SQLite DB: `~/Library/Messages/chat.db`
- Requires Full Disk Access (SIP protected)
- Read-only â€” cannot send via SQLite
- Sending: Use AppleScript or `osascript` (limited, may need Accessibility permissions)

## 5. TCC Permissions Guide

### How TCC Works for CLI Tools
- TCC (Transparency, Consent, Control) controls access to protected data
- For CLI tools, TCC identifies the **binary path** or its **parent terminal app**
- First access triggers a system prompt (or is denied if terminal lacks permission)
- Permissions granted to Terminal.app / iTerm carry to child processes

### Permission Matrix

| Data/Framework | TCC Service | First-Run Behavior | Entitlement Needed? |
|---------------|-------------|--------------------|--------------------|
| **Calendars** | kTCCServiceCalendar | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Reminders** | kTCCServiceReminders | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Contacts** | kTCCServiceAddressBook | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Location** | kTCCServiceLocation | System prompt + Location Services ON | No (for dev) |
| **Photos** | kTCCServicePhotos | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Camera** | kTCCServiceCamera | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Microphone** | kTCCServiceMicrophone | System prompt | No (for dev) |
| **Full Disk** | kTCCServiceSystemPolicyAllFiles | Must grant in System Preferences | No |
| **Automation** | kTCCServiceAppleEvents | System prompt per target app | No |
| **Bluetooth** | kTCCServiceBluetoothAlways | System prompt | No (for dev) |

### Key Points
- **No code signing or entitlements needed** for development CLI tools
- The terminal app (Terminal.app, iTerm, etc.) needs the permission
- Once Terminal.app is granted Contacts access, ALL CLI tools run from it get access
- **Full Disk Access** must be manually granted in System Settings > Privacy
- For **distribution**, you'd need proper signing + entitlements + notarization

### Granting Permissions Programmatically
You can't. But you can:
```bash
# Check if terminal has permission (by trying the operation)
# Open System Settings to the right pane:
open "x-apple.systempreferences:com.apple.preference.security?Privacy_Contacts"
open "x-apple.systempreferences:com.apple.preference.security?Privacy_Reminders"
open "x-apple.systempreferences:com.apple.preference.security?Privacy_AllFiles"
```

---

## 6. swift-argument-parser

### Basic Pattern
```swift
import ArgumentParser

struct MyCLI: ParsableCommand {
    static let configuration = CommandConfiguration(
        abstract: "Tool description",
        subcommands: [List.self, Add.self]
    )
}

extension MyCLI {
    struct List: ParsableCommand {
        @Option(name: .shortAndLong, help: "Filter by category")
        var category: String?
        
        @Flag(name: .shortAndLong, help: "Show verbose output")
        var verbose = false
        
        func run() throws {
            // implementation
        }
    }
    
    struct Add: ParsableCommand {
        @Argument(help: "Item to add")
        var item: String
        
        func run() throws {
            // implementation
        }
    }
}

MyCLI.main()
```

### For AI-Generated Code: Skip It
**Recommendation:** For agent-generated tools, **don't use swift-argument-parser**. Instead:
```swift
// Simple argument handling without dependencies
let args = CommandLine.arguments
guard args.count > 1 else {
    print("Usage: tool <command> [args...]")
    exit(1)
}
let command = args[1]
```
**Why:** Saves 25 seconds of build time, no dependency fetching, simpler code, fewer things to get wrong.

---

## 7. How Existing macOS CLI Tools Are Built

### mas (Mac App Store CLI)
- **Language:** Swift
- **Build:** SPM with swift-argument-parser
- **Architecture:** Subcommands (install, search, list, upgrade)
- **macOS APIs:** StoreKit (private frameworks), NSWorkspace
- **Key insight:** Uses private Apple APIs â€” not something an AI should generate

### accli (Apple Calendar CLI)
- **Approach:** Likely EventKit-based
- **Pattern:** Simple read/write operations on EKEventStore

### imsg (iMessage CLI)
- **Approach:** SQLite read from `~/Library/Messages/chat.db` + AppleScript for sending
- **Limitation:** Requires Full Disk Access

### Common Patterns
1. All use Swift + SPM
2. Most wrap a single Apple framework
3. Argument parsing via swift-argument-parser or manual
4. Async operations use semaphores or RunLoop

---

## 8. Swift vs Python vs Node for AI-Generated CLIs

### Comparison Matrix

| Factor | Swift (single-file) | Swift (SPM) | Python | Node.js |
|--------|-------------------|-------------|---------|---------|
| **Compile/run time** | 0.3s compile + instant | 14-26s first, 1.5s incremental | Instant (interpreted) | Instant (interpreted) |
| **macOS API access** | âœ… Full native | âœ… Full native | âŒ Minimal (pyobjc works but clunky) | âŒ None native |
| **AI code reliability** | âš ï¸ Medium | âš ï¸ Medium | âœ… High | âœ… High |
| **Error handling** | Strict (Swift 6 concurrency) | Strict | Permissive | Permissive |
| **No-install needed** | âœ… (Xcode CLT) | âœ… (Xcode CLT) | âœ… (system Python) | âš ï¸ (needs node) |
| **Readability** | Good | Good | Excellent | Good |
| **Binary size** | ~1MB | ~1MB | N/A | N/A |

### Recommendation: Hybrid Approach

**Use single-file Swift (`swiftc`) for:**
- Anything needing native macOS frameworks (EventKit, Contacts, CoreLocation, etc.)
- Tasks that need ScriptingBridge or NSAppleScript
- Performance-critical tools

**Use Python for:**
- Data processing, text manipulation
- Web API calls
- Anything not needing native macOS APIs
- Quick prototyping

**Use shell (osascript) for:**
- Simple AppleScript one-liners
- Quick Notes/Calendar/Reminders reads
- When you just need one piece of data

### The Sweet Spot: Single-File Swift
```bash
# AI generates tool.swift, compiles and runs in <1 second
swiftc tool.swift -o /tmp/tool && /tmp/tool
```

---

## 9. AI Code Generation â€” Gotchas & Patterns

### Common Swift Gotchas for AI

1. **Swift 6 Concurrency Strictness**
   - Swift 6 enforces `Sendable` and actor isolation
   - AI often generates code that worked in Swift 5 but fails in Swift 6
   - **Fix:** Add `-swift-version 5` flag or use `@preconcurrency import`
   ```bash
   swiftc -swift-version 5 tool.swift -o tool  # Bypass Swift 6 strictness
   ```

2. **RunLoop Requirement**
   - Delegate-based APIs (CoreLocation, CoreBluetooth) need RunLoop
   - AI forgets this â†’ callbacks never fire
   - **Always include:** `RunLoop.main.run(until: Date(timeIntervalSinceNow: N))`

3. **Async/Await in CLI**
   - Can't just call `await` in main.swift top-level
   - Need: `@main struct Tool { static func main() async throws { ... } }`

4. **macOS Version Availability**
   - `requestFullAccessToReminders` is macOS 14+ 
   - Use `if #available(macOS 14.0, *)` guards
   - **Or target older API:** `requestAccess(to: .reminder)`

5. **TCC Silent Failures**
   - If permission denied, many APIs return empty data (not errors!)
   - Always check authorization status explicitly

6. **AVAudioSession is iOS-only**
   - AI trained on iOS code will use it â€” it doesn't exist on macOS
   - Use `AVCaptureDevice` for audio device access on macOS

7. **String Encoding in AppleScript Results**
   - NSAppleScript returns `NSAppleEventDescriptor`
   - Need to extract with `.stringValue`, `.numberOfItems`, `.atIndex()`
   - Off-by-one: AppleScript arrays are 1-indexed

### Reliable Templates for AI Generation

#### Template: Read Data from macOS Framework
```swift
#!/usr/bin/env swift
import Foundation
import <FRAMEWORK>

let semaphore = DispatchSemaphore(value: 0)
var output: [String] = []

// Request access
<store>.request<Access> { granted, error in
    guard granted else {
        print("ERROR: Access denied")
        semaphore.signal()
        return
    }
    // Fetch data
    // ... append to output ...
    semaphore.signal()
}

semaphore.wait()
// Output as JSON for machine consumption
let json = try JSONSerialization.data(withJSONObject: output)
print(String(data: json, encoding: .utf8)!)
```

#### Template: AppleScript Bridge
```swift
#!/usr/bin/env swift
import Foundation

let script = NSAppleScript(source: """
    tell application "<APP_NAME>"
        <APPLESCRIPT_COMMANDS>
    end tell
""")!

var error: NSDictionary?
let result = script.executeAndReturnError(&error)
if let error = error {
    fputs("ERROR: \(error)\n", stderr)
    exit(1)
}
print(result.stringValue ?? "")
```

#### Template: SQLite Reader
```swift
#!/usr/bin/env swift
import Foundation
import SQLite3

var db: OpaquePointer?
let path = NSString(string: "<DB_PATH>").expandingTildeInPath
guard sqlite3_open_v2(path, &db, SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY, nil) == SQLITE_OK else {
    print("ERROR: Cannot open database")
    exit(1)
}
defer { sqlite3_close(db) }

var stmt: OpaquePointer?
let query = "<SQL_QUERY>"
guard sqlite3_prepare_v2(db, query, -1, &stmt, nil) == SQLITE_OK else {
    print("ERROR: \(String(cString: sqlite3_errmsg(db)))")
    exit(1)
}
defer { sqlite3_finalize(stmt) }

while sqlite3_step(stmt) == SQLITE_ROW {
    let col0 = String(cString: sqlite3_column_text(stmt, 0))
    print(col0)
}
```

---

## 10. Practical Architecture for AI Agent

### Recommended Approach
```
Agent wants macOS data
    â†“
Is it simple? (one value, list)
    â†’ YES: Use osascript one-liner
    â†’ NO: Generate single-file Swift
           â†“
       swiftc -swift-version 5 tool.swift -o /tmp/tool
           â†“
       /tmp/tool [args]
           â†“
       Parse stdout (JSON preferred)
```

### Pre-Built Tool Library
Instead of generating every time, maintain a library of tested Swift CLIs:
```
builds/swift-tools/
â”œâ”€â”€ reminders.swift      # List/add/complete reminders
â”œâ”€â”€ calendars.swift      # List/add/search events  
â”œâ”€â”€ contacts.swift       # Search/list contacts
â”œâ”€â”€ notes-read.swift     # Read notes via AppleScript
â”œâ”€â”€ location.swift       # Get current location
â”œâ”€â”€ photos-search.swift  # Search photo library
â””â”€â”€ app-control.swift    # Generic AppleScript bridge
```

### Build Once, Run Many
```bash
# Build all tools once
for f in builds/swift-tools/*.swift; do
    swiftc -swift-version 5 "$f" -o "builds/swift-tools/$(basename "$f" .swift)"
done

# Then just run the binary (instant)
builds/swift-tools/reminders list
builds/swift-tools/contacts search "John"
```

---

## 11. Quick Reference: One-Liners

```bash
# List all reminders
swiftc -swift-version 5 -e '
import EventKit; import Foundation
let s = EKEventStore(); let sem = DispatchSemaphore(value: 0)
s.requestFullAccessToReminders { g, _ in
    let p = s.predicateForIncompleteReminders(withDueDateStarting: nil, ending: nil, calendars: nil)
    s.fetchReminders(matching: p) { r in
        r?.forEach { print($0.title ?? "") }; sem.signal()
    }
}; sem.wait()
'

# List contacts
osascript -e 'tell application "Contacts" to get name of every person'

# Get calendar events today
osascript -e 'tell application "Calendar" to get summary of every event of calendar "Home" whose start date > (current date)'

# Read Notes titles
osascript -e 'tell application "Notes" to get name of every note'
```

---

## Summary & Recommendations

1. **Single-file Swift + swiftc** is the best approach for AI-generated macOS CLI tools (0.3s compile)
2. **All major frameworks work** from CLI Swift â€” no Xcode project needed
3. **TCC permissions flow through the terminal** â€” grant once, all tools work
4. **Use `-swift-version 5`** to avoid Swift 6 concurrency strictness issues
5. **Always use semaphores** for async operations in CLI context
6. **Output JSON** from tools for machine parsing
7. **Pre-build common tools** rather than generating fresh each time
8. **For Notes.app:** Use AppleScript bridge (NSAppleScript or osascript), not SQLite
9. **Python for non-native tasks**, Swift only when you need macOS frameworks
10. **Watch for:** RunLoop requirements, macOS version guards, TCC silent failures

# Math4Sale.com â€” Dan Kariv's Calculator Business

## Overview
Matt is consulting/helping Dan Kariv build a growth funnel to scale school sales from $600K to $5M annually while reducing Amazon dependency (currently 95.5% of revenue).

## Business Profile
- **Domain:** math4sale.com
- **Owner:** Dan Kariv
- **Head of Ops:** Oliver
- **Product:** Texas Instruments calculators (new, open-box/institutional, factory renewed)
- **CRM:** Pipedrive
- **Email:** Instantly (domains already warmed)
- **Site:** Shopify (Dylan coordinating)
- **History:** 20 years in business, ~1M calculators sold
- **Current revenue split:** 95.5% Amazon, ~$600K schools

## Core SKUs (5 products, 3 families)
| SKU | Price/Unit | Notes |
|-----|-----------|-------|
| TI-83 Plus | $60-65 | Entry level |
| TI-84 Plus | $80-85 | **#1 school driver** (battery-powered, no charging needed) |
| TI-84 Plus School Property | $80-85 | Yellow version of 84 |
| TI-84 CE | $95-120 | Premium |
| TI-84 CE School Property | $95-120 | Yellow CE variant |

Average unit price: ~$80. Margins: ~50%.

## Target Market

- **Secondary:** Public school districts (more process/RFQs, harder)
- **Sweet spot:** Schools with 500+ employees

## Order Sizes
- Small: ~30 units / $2,500 (credit card)
- Mid: ~100 units / $8,500-10,000

## Key Metrics
- **60% repeat purchase rate** from existing school customers
- **95% close rate** on quote requests
- **50% open rate, 20% reply rate** on previous email campaign
- **0% return rate** from schools (vs 8% Amazon)
- **21.5% lower cost** than selling through Amazon
- ~600 schools in customer base

## Credibility Indicators
- 20 years in business
- ~1M calculators sold
- 10,000+ Amazon reviews, 30,000+ eBay reviews
- A+ BBB rating
- Major clients: Department of Defense, K-12 Inc., Epic Charter Schools, National Math & Science Initiative, Bloomfield College

- 1-year exchange warranty (vs TI's 5-6 week repair)

## Value Proposition
- **Budget flexibility** â€” "I have $10K, what can I get?" They work the math.
- **Speed** â€” targeting 5-10 second AI-powered quotes
- **No risk** â€” 90-day returns, 1-year exchange warranty
- **Ease** â€” "Get this off Sally's to-do list"
- **Three pricing tiers** (SaaS-style):
  1. New (5-10% savings)
  2. Institutional Packaging / Open-Box New (10-20% savings)
  3. Factory Renewed (max savings)

## School Savers Acquisition
- **Owner:** Bill (planning to retire)
- **Location:** California
- **Lease ending:** November 2026
- **Status:** Bill talking to TI next week, Dan meeting him Friday
- **Value:** Makes Dan a TI authorized distributor â†’ access to ALL TI, HP, Casio products
- **Strategic:** School revenue at 5-6x multiple vs Amazon â†’ $600K school rev = ~$3M exit value, $5M school rev = $8-10M exit value
- **Competitor note:** Underwood Distribution (young owner) acquired a similar business 2 years ago â€” Dan missed that one

## Competitive Landscape
- **16 total TI authorized distributors** (most have outdated sites/slow quotes)
- **Underwood Distribution** â€” best competitor, young owner, good website, aggressive (sue-happy about site similarities), conquest ad target
- **School Savers** â€” Bill retiring, acquisition target
- **EAI Education** â€” large ed supply company, has CalcSafe sub-brand
- **Calculatorti.com (Beach Audio)** â€” large company, less competitive
- **Eldorado Group** â€” another competitor

## Action Items

### Immediate (Matt's scope)
- [ ] Meet with Bill (School Savers) on Friday after his TI conversation
- [ ] Build 5 dedicated landing pages (one per SKU) â€” focus on quote form above the fold
- [ ] Develop AI-powered instant quote system (5-10 second delivery, natural language input)
- [ ] Create brand package: explainer video, presentation deck, infographic, enhanced quote template
- [ ] Coordinate with Dylan on Shopify site development
- [ ] Gather Amazon review counts by SKU for Okendo integration
- [ ] Set up Google Ads: 10-pack searches + competitor conquest ads (Underwood, School Savers, Eldorado)
- [ ] Build and warm up email servers for outbound campaigns
- [ ] Compile target school lists (virtual, charter, private with 500+ employees)
- [ ] Research AI solution for monitoring OpenGov and bid sites
- [ ] Send current quote templates to Matt for reference

### Landing Page Design
- **One page per SKU** â€” quote form above the fold, that's it
- **Layout:** Left side = trust/value props, Right side = quote form
- **Below fold:** Reviews (Okendo), "20 years in business", credibility badges
- **No clutter** â€” competitors have slow, bloated sites with captchas. Be the opposite.
- **Competitor weakness:** Underwood has Apple Pay checkout but schools can't use it (need quote approval process). Their site speed is terrible.
- **Reference:** Dan made a mockup screenshot Matt liked â€” clean, simple, fast
- **Ad flow:** Google Ad â†’ SKU-specific landing page with that product pre-populated ("You came to the right place") â†’ quote form â†’ call from Dan
- **Quote form fields:** Quantity, email, name, phone (optional but helps for personal follow-up call)
- **Remove from current site:** Subject field, PO upload (can ask later), excess navigation
- **Current site (math4sale.com):** Outdated, too complex, below-fold content nobody sees. Full rebuild needed.
- **Dylan** handles Shopify build + coding. Matt handles design direction.

### Google Shopping Strategy
- Install Okendo on Shopify â†’ import Amazon reviews â†’ Google rich snippets with stars
- Underwood shows "14% off" in shopping results â€” replicate with own discount messaging
- Star ratings in shopping results = massive CTR advantage (visual standout vs competitors without)
- Calculatorti.com (Beach Audio) bidding but overpriced ($143 bulk) â€” easy to beat on price

### Marketing Strategy
**Google Ads:**

- Conquest ads against Underwood, School Savers, Eldorado

- Note: Underwood is selling USED calculators, not new â€” competitive advantage

**Email Outbound:**
- Re-engage existing 600 school customers first (60% repurchase = immediate revenue)
- Build lists from public data: top charter schools, virtual schools, private schools
- Instantly infrastructure already set up with warmed domains
- Previous campaign: 50% open, 20% reply

**Direct Mail:**

**Seasonality:**
- Orders year-round (not just back-to-school)

### Quote Experience (Key Differentiator)
- AI form accepts natural language ("I need 100 of these")
- Collects: quantity, SKU, email, name
- Generates quote in 5-10 seconds
- Human oversight for error checking
- Personal follow-up call from Dan after quote submission
- Beautiful brand package with: company overview, three pricing tiers (SaaS-style), video, trust indicators

### Phase 2 â€” Secondary Opportunities
- **Recycling center partnerships:** Source inventory at 10Â¢/lb (scrap rate) vs 30Â¢ on dollar. Can repair 80% of calculators. Most centers currently disposing as waste.
- **Bid monitoring:** AI scanning OpenGov for calculator RFPs, thousands of relevant bids currently unmonitored
- **Ed tech expansion:** After School Savers acquisition, expand product lines â†’ PE-attractive B2B education company

## Key Numbers
- **Target:** Grow total revenue to $12.5M. $3-5M from schools, rest from Amazon.

- **CAC tolerance:** $1,000+ per customer is fine given order sizes ($2,500-$100K+)

### Journal Technique (July 2018)
A structured emotional processing framework:
1. Define the trigger â€” what happened
2. "Release the rage" â€” get it all out
3. List actual facts vs. story you're telling yourself
4. "If that story is true I feel..."
5. What actions do you want to take when feeling those things?
6. What evidence that the story is true? Is it 100% true?
7. "If it was false what would be possible"
8. What do I want for me, what do I want for us?
9. "Walking the block" â€” the drift and shift technique
10. Reframe: original story â†’ me version â†’ opposite â†’ desired story
11. "This trigger was positive because it gave me X lesson"
12. Meditate, listen to the voice, connect other events

### Shiv's Emotional Framework (Aug 2018)
Step 1: Write down emotions accurately. "What really happened. I feel like... what are the emotions I am experiencing"
Step 2: Question the underlying why. "Am I being a victim. Am I showing up with scarcity or abundance."
Step 3: Examine underlying beliefs. "Are those beliefs aligned with values. Question the believes and extract values."

## Personal Growth Database (Read: 2025-07-27)

22 pages. This is a GOLDMINE of personal insight.

### ðŸ”‘ Huberman Journaling Protocol â€” The Most Revealing Document in Matt's Entire Notion

Matt did Andrew Huberman's 4-day journaling protocol about a stressful/traumatic experience. He chose his **childhood brain tumor**. This is the most raw, vulnerable writing in his entire archive.

**Day 1 â€” The Brain Tumor Story:**
> "When I was 6 or 7 I was bragging to my parents that I could see air molecules. Then I went to the doctor and had an MRI and came out that I had a brain tumor. At the time no one knew if it was growing quickly or what was going on but the doctors were pretty sure it was inoperable as it had a high chance of killing me or leaving me blind."

> "I remember going to UCSF to get multiple brain scans and seeing the other young kids with screws coming out of their skulls holding them together. I remember thinking wow am I going to have to go through that?"

**The outcome:** The tumor was NOT growing â€” "most likely was a piece of fatty tissue that formed in my brain." But the psychological impact was permanent.

**Death anxiety â€” his constant companion:**
> "On the drive here I was wondering if I stopped focusing I could run us off the road and kill us, or that a car could just veer into our lane at any moment and kill us in a head on collision."

> "I remember worrying a lot when my mom was late that she was killed in a car accident and that I would lose her. These emotions were VERY strong and I remember panicking at times."

> "I think about [the death of my parents] almost everyday."

**Photography as therapy:**
> "I'm really happy I'm investing more into that hobby as it's a form of journaling and documenting the beauty of my existence. Someday I hope my kids will see all of the beauty of the world in the same way that I have experienced it."

**Why he's addicted to productivity:**
> "I think I used learning as a zone of comfort and distraction from those early emotions as a child and still use distraction as a way of getting away from those scary thoughts."

> "I do feel addicted to my phone and the stimulation of learning as it keeps me from downregulating and relaxing."

**Day 2 â€” School and emotional walls:**
> "By walling off my emotions it led me to stand out from my peer groups in grade school. I barely reacted to stuff and therefore caused people to try and trigger me."

> "I remember making this number grid and I went sooo above and beyond... I had done by far the most of anyone ever. I did this because it was a release, I wanted to feel seen. And I wanted to be the best."

> "Imagine potentially dying as a 7 year old and not being allowed to tell anyone."

**His parents' approach:** They didn't tell his sister Lauren about the tumor. They didn't want Matt telling anyone because "they thought people would treat me differently or that it would hurt my career aspirations."

**Jake's family as emotional refuge:**
> "I am thankful for Jake's family because they were better at communication and talking about emotions. I felt sometimes more love/understood from Jake's family than my own."

**Day 3 â€” Positive and negative impacts:**
Lists 10 impacts including: "It made me build emotional walls because I didn't want to show I was scared or hurting," "It made me a bit afraid of dying too soon," "It helped me stay calm under pressure," "It made me avoidant under intense situations."

**What he'd tell his child self:**
> "It's all going to be ok, you are brave and none of this is your fault. It's a traumatic experience for you but also for your parents who are watching their most sacred thing be possibly taken away from them. It's ok to cry, it's ok to feel it all, to surrender to the chaos and unknowing."

**Day 4 â€” Potential violence from his father:**
> "I got the feeling he may have hit me as a kid a few times, and maybe even my sister. I don't know if this is real or not but the fact that he got so angry with my mom that she had bruises and took pictures on her phone is telling. He apparently twisted her arm with max force."

> "I do remember him chasing me around the house because I said I was going to visit Sarah. He said no, I said yes, and he chased me around and tried to swing but missed. I jumped over the couch knowing I was just as fast. He stormed out to the truck and ripped out some cables so the engine wouldn't run."

**Amy as his current partner:**
> "Amy last night was so supportive and perfect with me. Never wavering, strong, and made me feel safe. It was fantastic to see that side of her and made me feel a lot more comfortable to know she can be that role."

> "I'm really happy that Amy is in my life to show me the ways of [emotional communication]. Her family is very communicative."

**Bed-wetting and shame:**
> "I also had a lot of memories and shame around wetting the bed. I did it almost every night and remember trying so hard not to but then it would happen every day."

> "A lot of my psychedelic journeys involve relaxing and surrendering so much to the point of wetting myself, wetness and warmth definitely seem to be a theme."

**The closing quote he chose (Dalio):**
> "I found that when I reached each new higher level of success, I rarely remained satisfied... Eventually the success of mission and well being of the people alongside me became more important than my success."

## COMPLETE PSYCHOLOGICAL PROFILE â€” Who Matt DeCelles IS

### The Core Wound
At age 6-7, Matt discovered he had a brain tumor after "seeing air molecules." The tumor was likely benign fatty tissue, but for a period, his family lived with the possibility it was inoperable and could kill or blind him. His parents' response â€” silence, not telling his sister, not letting Matt tell anyone â€” created a foundational pattern: **suppress emotions, perform excellence, stay productive to avoid feeling.**

### The Resulting Architecture
1. **Productivity as emotional avoidance** â€” "I used learning as a zone of comfort and distraction from those early emotions"
2. **Emotional walls** â€” "I'm incredibly terrible with emotions" (Libby letter). Built walls to not show fear, which made him cool under pressure but emotionally disconnected
3. **Death anxiety** â€” constantly thinks about death, catastrophizes, fears losing parents
4. **Performance as identity** â€” the number grid obsession, wanting to be seen, wanting to be the best
5. **Systematic approach to everything** â€” dating, emotions, charisma, morning routines â€” all get frameworks

### What He Loves

- Wants to be a Renaissance man (23 skills he wants to master)
- Wants to surpass Steve Jobs (per Zach's assessment)

## LIFE GOALS â€” Matt's Magnum Opus (Read: 2026-01-27)
*Matt called this "the most important doc I've ever created" and his "magnum opus"*

This is a comprehensive life blueprint document. 735 blocks across 8 pages. Covers every dimension of who Matt wants to be.

# Nightly Builds - Stanley's Workshop

## Concept
Every night while Matt sleeps, Stanley builds one small tool that improves their workflow.
Scope: small, useful, surprising. Something Matt can test when he wakes up.

## Build Ideas (Backlog)
Priority order â€” most impactful first:

1. **Session Recovery Dashboard** - HTML page that shows current session state, active sub-agents, recent context. Survives compaction.
2. **Morning Briefing Generator** - Script that checks email, calendar, weather, and generates a morning summary.
3. **Memory Search CLI** - Fast local search across all memory files (grep + fzf style) with a nice HTML viewer.
4. **Notion Inbox Triage Tool** - HTML dashboard of the 950 inbox items, filterable by theme/priority/date.
5. **Daily Standup Bot** - Auto-generates a "what Stanley did today" summary from daily logs.
6. **Kanban Board v2** - Upgrade the existing board with drag-drop, persistence, and Notion sync.
7. **API Key Manager** - Secure local vault for all API keys with easy rotation.
8. **Conversation Export** - Clean export of our best conversations to markdown/PDF.
9. **mem0 Dashboard** - HTML viewer for all stored memories with search and edit.
10. **Quick Actions Panel** - HTML command palette for common tasks (check email, weather, calendar, etc.)

## Completed Builds

1. **Session Recovery Dashboard** (2026-01-31) â€” Dark-mode HTML dashboard showing system health, ticket summary, task overview, cron status, and quick links. Auto-refreshes every 2 minutes. Deployed at: https://kanban-vercel-kappa.vercel.app/session.html?token=matt2026stanley. Source: ~/clawd/builds/session-dashboard/
2. **Memory Search CLI** (2026-02-01) â€” Fast local search across 83 memory files (1.2MB). Dark-mode HTML viewer with keyword highlighting, file type filters (daily/people/projects/learnings), context preview. Press / to focus search. Source: ~/clawd/builds/memory-search/. Run build-index.sh to refresh.
3. **Bitcoin Mayer Multiple Fix** (2026-02-01) â€” Fixed stale price bug: swapped blockchain.info chart API (24h delayed) for Coinbase live spot price. Historical data still from blockchain.info for 200WMA calculations. Deployed to stanley-dashboard.vercel.app.

## Rules
- One build per night
- Must be functional by morning
- Include a README or demo
- Save to ~/clawd/builds/{project-name}/
- Log what was built in daily memory file

## Asana <-> Kanban Two-Way Sync
- Build webhook sync between Asana My Tasks and kanban board (kanban-vercel-kappa.vercel.app)
- Asana webhooks â†’ update kanban when tasks are moved/completed/created in Asana
- Kanban API â†’ update Asana when tasks change on kanban side
- Section mapping: MUST DO = urgent/high todo, LATER LIST = medium/low todo, WATCH LIST = in-progress, DONE = done
- Fallback: cron sync every hour checking both sides for changes
- Each task has [kanban#ID] in Asana notes for cross-referencing
- Needs: Vercel serverless endpoint to receive Asana webhooks
- Priority: HIGH (Matt requested explicitly)

## ~~Fix Bitcoin Mayer Multiple Stale Price~~ âœ… DONE (2026-02-01)
- Fixed: now uses Coinbase API for live price, blockchain.info for historical only

- **Aviation dynasty**: Grandpa (ALPA safety), Phil (Delta captain), Joe (pilot)

# Notion Batch 6A Report â€” Personal & Inner World Databases
*Processed: 2026-01-30 by Stanley (subagent: notion-batch-6a-personal)*
*Focus: READ ONLY â€” Matt's personal growth, relationships, beliefs, routines, and inner world*

## Summary
- **Databases queried**: 19
- **Databases with content**: 9 (Journal, Journal 2nd, Goals, Gratitude, Routines, Personal Growth Courses, Mentee Material, Love, Libby)
- **Databases empty**: 10 (Goals 2nd, Values, Beliefs, Habits, Priorities, Dreams that are Happening, Life Coach, Aspirational Mentors, Family, Friends)
- **Total pages with content**: ~67
- **Major discoveries**: Deeply emotional letters to Libby, Ayahuasca experience, personal mission statement/affirmations, MBTI results (ENTP-T), Singularity University involvement, HearNow pitch to Trunk Club, CSP nonprofit work

## Critical Discoveries

### 1. Matt's Personal Mission Statement (from Morning Routine)
**This is the core of who Matt aspires to be:**
> "My definite major purpose is to live a long, healthy life. Full of vitality and adventure. To love and experience love daily. To contribute in my work and create something that will last beyond myself. To inspire others through action, resolve and boldness. To master myself and develop a relationship with God. To be the best version of myself as often as possible (essence: Love, Positivity, Connection, Vision, Leader.) To act from principle and not gratification; from love and not contempt, fear or anger."

**His promise to himself:**
> "I promise to love myself fully and deeply. To accept myself for my strengths and shortcomings and to love others in the same way. I promise to spend my time, talent and treasure on creating experiences and structures that make people's lives better. I promise to stay true to myself and to share the gifts, blessings and wisdom I've been given."

**His mission:** "To create experiences and structures that make people's lives better."
**His vision:** "To authentically develop the world."

### 2. Matt's MBTI: ENTP-T ("The Debater")
- **Variant:** Turbulent
- **Role:** Analyst
- **Strategy:** Social Engagement
- Extraverted (51%), Intuitive (62%), Thinking (68%), Prospecting (52%), Turbulent (36%)
- Libby was ESFJ ("The Consul") â€” complementary types

### 3. Libby â€” The Most Significant Past Relationship
**11 pages dedicated to Libby â€” the most documented relationship in the entire Notion archive.**

#### The Breakup Letter (deeply vulnerable)
- Matt broke up with Libby due to her alcoholism
- He recognized he was "incredibly terrible with emotions" and how that harmed the relationship
- Key self-awareness: "I realize now how incredibly terrible I am with emotions and how that effected our relationship... Being in a relationship with someone who is not connected with their emotions must have been incredibly frustrating, painful, and difficult"
- He described himself as "hyper focused on efficiency and productivity" and not being present during amazing moments
- He acknowledged: "I was so caught up in my head, totally disconnected, and completely distracted all of the time"
- About her alcoholism: "I would give up everything for you to accept that alcoholism is a real thing and that 100% you have it"
- He researched Al-Anon for himself (page saved about Al-Anon support groups)

#### The Follow-Up Letter (6 months later)
- Written 6 months post-breakup, still deeply in love
- She had told him: "I never loved you I love the idea of you" â€” this hurt him profoundly
- "Even 6 months later someone mentioning your name makes me feel like my heart is being ripped out of my chest"
- "I loved you with my entire being, and you not knowing that is one of the biggest regrets in my entire life"
- Repeated the same praise paragraphs â€” shows he had a template of what he loved about her

#### What Libby Represented to Matt
- She was his "foundation and stability"
- She helped him through "incredibly dark times"
- He loved her quirkiness, authenticity, zest for life, independence
- Key shared experiences: Arizona river float, Jason Kirby's wedding, Ryan's cancer charity event, Paulina's wedding, New York trip, BiPlane experience, pumpkin carving
- She was his most significant romantic relationship documented in the archive (~2015 era based on context clues)

#### Relationship Rules
- Page titled "Rules for Relationship" exists but was empty â€” suggests he set up a framework but never filled it

### 4. Love & Dating Philosophy (from "Love" database)
- Attributed to Andrew Ferebee
- Core principle: **"JUST FUCKING LET GO OF ALL EXTERNAL VALIDATIONS!!!"**
- Key mantras: Complete freedom from outcome, abundance mindset, make her feel good about herself
- Physical escalation ladder documented (spin handshake â†’ hug â†’ waltz â†’ high fives â†’ touch â†’ kiss)

### 5. Ayahuasca Experience (Journal)
**A vivid, joyful first-person account of an Ayahuasca ceremony in the Amazon jungle:**
- Purple liquid that tasted like "lemon juice with tree roots"
- Experienced vivid fractals, kaleidoscope visions, rainbow gradients
- Compared it to Disney's "It's a Small World" ride but "infinitely more complex"
- The shaman guided the journey through chanting, whistling, and singing

- Could not think about the past â€” only the present moment
- Referenced a brain tumor: "I thought back to the brain tumor and felt that it has triggered the meditation" â€” **NEW: Matt had a brain tumor at some point**
- Full of joy throughout, never felt sick
- Sat up the entire time (proud of this)
- Kept thinking about "Shaffer and Dan" and how he'd explain the experience
- "Matt Shaffer" was on his mind a lot â€” seems like a close friend
- Overall feeling: immense gratitude, joy, wonder

### 6. Emotional Processing Frameworks

#### Shiv's Emotional Framework
Matt documented a therapeutic emotional processing technique from someone named "Shiv":
1. Write down emotions accurately â€” what really happened
2. Question the underlying why â€” am I being a victim? Scarcity vs abundance mindset?
3. Examine underlying beliefs â€” are they aligned with values? Extract values from beliefs

#### Journal Technique (Therapeutic)
A detailed rage-release and cognitive reframing technique:
1. Define the trigger
2. Release the rage â€” get it all out
3. List actual facts vs. the story you're telling yourself
4. "If that story is true I feel..."
5. "What evidence do I have that that story is true?"
6. "Is that story 100% true?"
7. "If it was false what would be possible?"
8. "What do I want for me, what do I want for us?"
9. "Walking the block" â€” drift and shift technique
10. Find the desired story and lesson
- This is sophisticated CBT-adjacent work â€” Matt has done real emotional/therapeutic work

### 7. Morning/Afternoon/Evening Routines
**Deeply intentional daily structure (circa 2015):**

**Morning:**
- Wake with gratitude: "Thank God I'm alive!"
- Daily affirmation: "I am Blessed & Highly Favored. I have greatness within me."
- Dalai Lama quote recitation
- Mission/vision review
- Read, Meditate, Visualize, Journal, Affirm
- Exercise, Protein Shake, Breakfast
- "Eat the frog" â€” tackle priorities first
- List 5 people to contact daily
- Lao Tzu quote: "Knowing yourself is true wisdom. Mastering yourself is true power."

**Afternoon:**
- Re-read mission/affirmations
- Peppermint oil, yerba mate tea, jumping jacks
- 4 Rules (from Don Miguel Ruiz's "The Four Agreements"):

- **Undun** â€” Women's supportive t-shirt/tank brand ("Better than Braless"), patent-integrated support
  - Taglines: "Defy Gravi-Tee", "Shape. Support. Coverage. Comfort. Perfection."
  - Sizes: A-C Cup and D+ Cup
  - Colors: Black, Navy, Light Grey, Light Pink, Sage Green
  - Samples finished Dec 1, arriving Dec 3; goods in US ~Feb 8
  - 3PL: Continental (Seattle)
  - Alex â€” wholesale/shirt orders partner

### Strategy & Future Direction
- CRO optimization notes: Move content high, lifestyle imagery, strike-through pricing, 50% below buy button
- Looking to **transition to AI-resistant B2B recurring commercial contracts**
- Interest in businesses around SLO/Paso Robles/Templeton area
- Ideal acquisition: Baby boomer retiring, seller financing, existing customers, non-technical service business
- Want to avoid: automotive (FSD coming), restaurants, SaaS (AI-disrupted)
- Patrick's network in Paso Robles area is a key asset
- Stanley describes himself as "super good at finances with financial engineering" and marketing funnels

### Nomatic Giveaway
- William Painter x Nomatic End of Summer giveaway: $1,600 total value, two winners
- WP gift bag: glasses + Chain & Link silver jewelry ($800 value)
- Nomatic: Travel bag + McKinnon camera bag ($800 value)

---

## 2. HearNow Technologies (across ~8 databases, 100+ pages)

### Company Description
HearNow Technologies was a B2B IoT company that developed sensors + software to reinvent the post-delivery e-commerce experience. First company to combine IoT sensors with software for post-delivery customer engagement.

### Core Technology
- **IoT devices** placed in e-commerce packages (especially In-Home Try-On / IHTO boxes)
- Devices detected when packages were opened via light sensors
- Triggered real-time SMS conversations between customers and stylists
- Ran on **Verizon M2M cellular network**
- Hardware: Custom PCBs with cellular module, BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy), light sensors
- Software: Heroku-hosted platform (hearnow.herokuapp.com), stylist dashboards, management dashboards

### Hardware Details (Next-Gen Device)
- Removed GPS module/antenna to reduce cost
- Added power switch, BLE processor (Cypress chip)
- Component costs at volume: ~$16 (excluding cell modem)
  - BLE processor: $1-2, Cellular antenna: $1.50, Battery: $1.20, Light sensor: $1, PCB: $0.85, Plastics: $1
- Team: Seton Kasmir (HiTem Engineering - hardware), Dragan Vuletic (firmware), Tom Dvornik (operations/software)

### Key Metrics (Bungalow Trial)
- **70% conversion rate** with text exchanges (vs 50% without)
- Text exchange average value per shipment: **$231.11**
- No-text average value per shipment: **$170.12**
- Trial time: 5 days
- Average box value: $1,208
- 66% buy 1+ item
- Average order value: $271-$318
- 52% scheduled buying

### Value Propositions
1. Accelerate business/sales
2. Real-time customer feedback
3. Human connection, customer loyalty, reduce churn
4. Shorten sales cycle
5. Increase sales
6. Referral opportunity
7. Empower stylists with real-time data
8. Quality assurance training
9. Response time tracking
10. Competitive advantage over Trunk Club

### Pricing Tiers
- **Low (<$200):** Hardware, warranty, interaction data, stylist notification on open
- **Professional ($201-$500):** Company dashboard (TV display), stylist dashboard, after-action reports, data parsing
- Lease model preferred (12-month warranty included)

### Key People
- **Matt DeCelles** â€” Co-founder, CEO (matt@hearnowtech.com)
- **Patrick Eckstein** â€” Co-founder (patrick@hearnowtech.com)
- **Steve** â€” Co-founder (steve@hearnowtech.com)
- **Jim Cleary** â€” Lead investor / board member (Karmel Capital?)
- **Scott** â€” Investor (scott@karmelcap.com)
- **Christian Buckley** â€” Lawyer/advisor (ccbuckley@cox.net, also from BFTEP)
- **Tom Dvornik** â€” Engineering/Operations (amphro@gmail.com)
- **Seton Kasmir** â€” Hardware engineering (HiTem Engineering)
- **Dragan Vuletic** â€” Firmware developer

### Investor & Business Context
- **Tylt Ventures** â€” Invested; philosophy: "Inclined to Innovate"; provided Shared Services Platform
- **UPS Strategic Enterprise Fund** â€” Potential investor contact
- **SDVG Cool Companies 2015** â€” HearNow selected (exhibited at 15th Annual Venture Summit, 700 attendees)
- Investment milestone structure: $100K with 3 milestones:
  1. Get Bungalow to buy
  2. Build VC-ready roadmap/presentation
  3. Meet with legitimate 3rd-party investor

### Target Industries
- In-Home Try-On (primary: Bungalow, Trunk Club, Stitch Fix)
- Wine clubs (temperature tracking, referral offers)
- Aerospace (tracking expensive parts, GE/Rolls Royce intros)
- Medical devices / In-Home Care
- Logistics
- Construction Tech

### The Pivot / End of Company
- **Founder Transition (Dec 2015):** Separation agreements for Jim and Scott (Tom?)
  - Stock vesting: 1M shares over 144 months, ~13-14 months vested
  - Repurchase price: $10 total for unvested shares
  - Matt retained all officer positions
- **HN Options analysis** (4 scenarios, all bleak):
  1. Raise large capital â€” no equity left, low valuation
  2. Partner with Montage â€” new device needed, slow sales cycle
  3. Small raise, no-device route â€” unproven, non-defensible
  4. Wind down
- **Final Steps:** Eliminate costs, file gov paperwork, get investor paperwork, recover Verizon deposit

### Financial Snapshot (Nov-Jan 2015-2016)
- **Monthly burn:** ~$20K+ (payroll $13K, taxes $6.5K, legal $1K+, insurance $282)
- **Nov 2015:** Started with $14.8K (checking + savings), ended at $0
- **Dec 2015:** $5K CC payment, $50K+ legal
- **Jan 2016:** CC balance $3,760; Checking $580; Savings $0

### Key Lessons from HN
- Christian Buckley's advice on handling problems: Alert â†’ Take responsibility â†’ Apologize â†’ Plan to fix â†’ Plan to prevent â†’ Gather feedback â†’ Thank everyone
- B2B sales: Map all stakeholders in large orgs (Filepicker article saved)
- Pitch framework: Define problem â†’ Explain solution â†’ Show data â†’ Close
- $8,200/month burn rate reduction identified as critical
- Hardware costs were the #1 challenge; needed to drive down costs significantly

## Tags

## Content Types
1. **Ephemeral** (grocery lists, one-off notes) â†’ delete or archive aggressively
2. **Snippets** (prompts, links, quick ideas) â†’ consolidate into databases/collections
3. **Reference/SOPs** (tutorials, guides, processes) â†’ keep structured, tag well

## Page-by-Page Actions
| Page | Action |
|------|--------|
| Notebook LM Slides Prompt | Move to Prompts & AI Tools |
| Grocery List | Delete (needs manual or retry) |
| Free Download Books | Merge into Resources & Links or delete |

| History in Glass Stack | ARCHIVE (dead project) |
| Claude Automated Email Marketing | Move to SOPs & Guides, tag #sop #ai #marketing |
| Resources & SOPs database | Keep, expand as organized hub |

## Matt's Answers (2026-01-27)
1. HearNow â†’ ARCHIVE (dead project)
2. History in Glass â†’ ARCHIVE (dead project)
3. Grocery List â†’ DELETE
4. Free ebooks page â†’ KEEP (feeds NotebookLM â€” important resource)

   - NotebookLM prompts

6. Future: Stanley gets X account to find and curate best prompts
7. Personal Stack â†’ Already read overnight, questions prepared
8. "Pictures to Remember" photos â†’ cherished memories, treat with care

## Lesson Learned
I proposed this whole plan and then only did the reading pass, not the actual reorganization. Don't just plan â€” execute.

## Execution Notes (2026-01-27)
- **EXECUTED** the full reorganization via Notion API
- Created 11-page organizational structure under Evernote Archive > Workspace Hub
- Moved 23+ pages to correct locations
- Quarantined 15+ sensitive pages

## CRITICAL: Recreate Pages, Don't Just Archive
Matt confirmed: the process must be READ â†’ CATEGORIZE â†’ CREATE NEW PAGE in correct destination â†’ ARCHIVE original.

### API Limitations Encountered

2. **Cannot archive workspace-level pages** â€” Grocery List and empty workspace pages couldn't be deleted via API.

### Could NOT Process (API limitations)
- **Grocery List** â€” workspace-level page, can't archive via API. Matt should delete manually.
- **Empty workspace pages** â€” can't archive workspace-level pages via API
- **2026-01-20T19:02:00...** â€” date-only workspace page, can't archive
- **Nano Banana Prompts database** â€” databases can't be moved via API, needs manual move to Prompts & AI Tools
- **Personal Stack** â€” intentionally left at workspace level (this is the ðŸ§  Personal section)

## Matt's Next Steps (Manual)
1. **Drag hub pages to workspace root** â€” Go to Evernote Archive â†’ Workspace Hub, then drag each section (Inbox, Reference, Projects, Archive, Quarantine) to the workspace sidebar
2. **Delete Grocery List** â€” It's a workspace-level page the API couldn't archive
3. **Move Nano Banana Prompts** database into Reference â†’ Prompts & AI Tools
4. **Move Evernote Archive** into Archive â†’ Evernote Historical
5. **Review Quarantine** â€” Some pages may have been incorrectly quarantined (Lamborghini listing, Radical Motorsport). Move non-sensitive ones back.
6. **Delete empty workspace pages** â€” A few untitled/empty pages at workspace level

## Workspace Statistics
- **Total items discovered**: 5,100+
- **Pages**: ~4,500
- **Databases/Data Sources**: ~600
- **Workspace-level pages**: ~15
- **Evernote Archive children**: ~4,800+ (the vast majority of content)

### Content Breakdown
The workspace is overwhelmingly Evernote import data (~95%). Major categories:
- **William Painter business** (product dev, marketing, ops, finance, meetings)
- **Bitcoin/crypto research** (investment theses, articles, tools)
- **Lamborghini Gallardo** (mods, parts, forums, maintenance)
- **Personal development** (therapy, ALA, reflections, goals)
- **Relationships** (Hatice, Libby, friends, family)
- **Business research** (DTC brands, manufacturing, acquisition targets)
- **Travel** (retreats, trips, restaurants)
- **Business cards** (dozens of scanned cards from events)

## New Things Learned About Matt

### From scanning 5,100+ page titles:
- **Entrepreneur House (E-House)**: Matt lived in an "EPIC Entrepreneur House" â€” a mastermind living situation with other entrepreneurs. Had house meetings, challenges, mastermind dinners.
- **Junto**: Matt was deeply involved in a "Franklin Junto" group (named after Ben Franklin's original). Regular meetings, business summits, goal-setting seminars.
- **ALA depth**: Multiple ALA levels (Level 1, Level 2, Level 3). This was a massive part of his personal development journey.
- **Hatice relationship**: Significant enough to have birthday notes, acknowledgments, reading lists shared, Turkey flight info, "Junto Hatice" meeting.
- **Phil BTC PUB KEY**: Matt's dad Phil is involved in Bitcoin too (has a public key stored in Notion).
- **Body of research**: Matt has done EXTENSIVE Bitcoin research â€” dozens of articles, investment theses, Twitter threads, podcast notes, books. Not casual â€” deeply committed.
- **Lamborghini obsession**: 50+ pages about Gallardo mods, parts, exhaust upgrades, wheels, head units. This car is a passion project.
- **Retreat culture**: Matt organizes and attends many retreats â€” house retreats, October retreats, Sedona, Joshua Tree, Big Bear. Values experiential connection.
- **Content creator**: Lots of video production notes â€” Final Cut Pro, Kickstarter videos, Facebook ad videos. Hands-on creator.
- **Knee surgery**: Had knee issues requiring surgery and physical therapy.
- **Bubble hotel/Treehouse interest**: Researched O2 Treehouse, TreeHouse Point, Campera Hotel Burbuja. Fascinated by unique accommodation experiences.

## Lessons Learned (For Future Notion Work)
1. Internal Notion integrations can't create workspace-level pages or archive them
2. Databases/data sources can't be moved via API
3. The search API is broad â€” a query for "recovery" will match "KuCoin recovery" AND "Radical Motorsport Recovery"
4. With 5,100+ items, batch processing is essential
5. Most of Matt's Notion is Evernote historical data â€” the active workspace is much smaller (~50-100 pages)

Nine Guiding Principles illustrate the aspirational Values Of Leaders that Mark Lefko imparts to others through his work. These are simple indicators provided with an understanding that they will be improved, adjusted and personalized, written in sand rather than etched in stone.
1. Respect
AÂ Â Leader hears, understands, accepts and honors people for who they are at their deepest level, witnessing their powerful authentic selves without judgment. A Conscious Leader appreciates and respects peopleâ€™s differences, holds a deep regard for their feelings and acknowledges their expressiveness and unique contribution to the world.Â Â Leadership requires respect of the differences in others.
2. Integrity
Acting with full integrity, a Leader is totally authentic, living with clarity of feelings and intentions, expressed through purpose and actions. This unmistakable authenticity is apparent to all when an individual is living with integrity it projects True Power. That individual exhibits trustworthiness that is unmistakable to others.
3. Transparency
A Leader aspires to be honest, real and as open as a book. True intentions, motivations and agendas are revealed without artifice or guile. The focus on straightforwardness, candor and accountability for actions, commitments and communication with others is constantly maintained. This transparency creates a safe space for others to access and share their own truths.
4. Co-Creation
Co-creation is pure, authentic, supportive collaboration with others. It allows Leaders to inspire and enable colleagues to participate in a shared purpose. It enables connections and the formation of quality relationships. It is unflinchingly generous and exploratory, and creates the potential for the discovery of unforeseen and treasured concepts.
5. Transformation
As the saying goes, â€œThe status-quo is an opiate.â€ A Leader embraces change as inevitable, necessary, productive, vital and empowering. It is this fundamental lack of resistance to change, this flexibility, that powers evolution, that fulfills the Leader personally and creates inspiring professional opportunities.
6. Love
â€œLoveâ€ in a business or management context is experienced and expressed by Leaders reflecting their self-awareness, openness, and comfort in sharing true feelings. The willingness to express this emotion, whether the actual word is used or not, communicates enthusiasm, appreciation and encouragement like nothing else. The feeling extends into the communication of empathy, support and connection, all critical components of the art ofÂ Â leadership.
7. Wholeness
A Leader is engaged in a life of balance, an embracing of the critical importance of the many aspects of existence that create the whole. Physical health through exercise, the importance of diet, an appreciation of the natural world, self-reflection and emotional health, recreation, a relationship with the divine, and intellectual curiosity combine to make this whole. Effective Leaders understand that personal fulfillment and success in career are achieved not simply by working harder or longer, but by balance and the practice of wholeness.
8. Courage
Fortified by the clarity of conviction, a Leader has the courage to proceed despite resistance, despite barriers, despite fear, despite ridicule and despite rejection. The strength derived from self-awareness, that calm inner-knowing, a commitment to integrity and the willingness to take responsibility, combine to permitÂ Â Leaders to jump, knowing that a net will be there to catch them.
9. Playfulness
Playfulness reflects a lightness of being, a willingness to not take oneself too seriously, a personal confidence and an expression of the joyfulness of life. These are the natural qualities of a Leader, allowing accessibility and denying the aloofness of the ivory tower. The vulnerability communicated by playfulness communicates a grace that dissolves tensions and encourages others to access and reveal their own truths.

2. Take the first step in faith. You don't have to see the whole staircase, just take the first step.Â -- Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
3. Act or accept.Â --Â Anonymous
4. Many great ideas go unexecuted, and many great executioners are without ideas. One without the other is worthless.Â -- Tim Blixseth
5. The world is more malleable than you think and it's waiting for you to hammer it into shape.Â -- Bono

        What is Lokad?
        
We optimize the thousands of supply chain decisions that your company needs to make every day: How much to purchase? How much to replenish? How much to rebalance from location A to B? How much to liquidate? Lokad optimizes such decisions with advanced probabilistic forecasts that analyze all possible futures against all possible decisions. 
        
Lokad delivers a combination of software+experts. With our software, your company gains access to the most advanced forecasting technology on the market that delivers probabilistic lead time forecasts and probabilistic demand forecasts.  Probabilistic forecasts outperform classic forecasts whenever inventory is involved.  
        
And thanks to our experts, your company gains access to expertise and dedication of our Lokad team. We are here to solve your supply chain challenges whatever it takes. Lokad features programmatic capabilities used by our experts in order to take into account all of your supply chain constraints: container shipments, minimum order quantities, shelf space capacity, etc.
ðŸ–¼ï¸ [image]
ROI and control
        
For every unit your company holds in stock, should this unit stay where it is today or should it be moved somewhere else? For every unit that your company could purchase or produce, should it be purchased or produced today? Operating your supply chain involves making all those decisions - every day, possibly many times a day, for every single unit of stock, for every single unit that could be in stock.
        
Excellence in supply chain management requires more than having the right vision and the right teams. Excellence also requires smart optimization of millions of decisions, rather than merely making decisions out of habit or inertia. In addition, the optimization process should take pretty much everything into account for every single decision: all historical data, all ordering or manufacturing constraints, all economic drivers.
        
Quantitative supply chain is the analysis of all possible futures against all possible decisions, and making  the best possible decisions based on their ROI (return on investment). The whole process requires full robotization so that it can be operated at any scale. Quantitative supply chain gives back the control of the supply chain to management by freeing up the companyâ€™s teams from mundane clerical tasks.

Then, to refine the results even further, we can include any additional relevant data: stock-out history, promotional history, competitors prices, etc.
        
Lokad offers data connectors for many popular apps. If your app is supported by Lokad, you can import all the relevant data into your Lokad account in just a few clicks.
        
Otherwise, you can also import your flat files (CSV, TSV, Excel) into Lokad. Files can be uploaded through the web or through protocols such as FTP, SFTP, FTPS. In fact, Lokad is able to handle very large quantities of files in various formats. We can even scale up to extremely large retail networks if needed.

This mid-year 911 Targa is now offered in Arizona with an ownerâ€™s manual, service records, a tool kit, spare parts, and a clean Montana title in the name of the sellerâ€™s LLC.

Iâ€™m not a buyerâ€¦ but a follower / owner of these and earlier carsâ€¦ and currently own a US Model Year 1974 (September 1973 built) 2.7 Carrera Coupe, a 1971 911 T converted into a 1973 RSR style car, and have owned many in the past since the mid 90sâ€¦
I feel compelled to help add some fact based clarity hereâ€¦ 
The headlight washers (snorkels) were an option that started in 1974 â€“ it is option number M288, and was available in 1975 as wellâ€¦ Motor Magazine (UK), tested a 1975 2.7 Carrera and in the 28 December 1974 issue clearly shows the snorkel headlight washers on their test car. They also did a comparison test against the Dino 246 in June 1975, and that car has them as wellâ€¦ It is also documented in Ryan Snodgrassâ€™s book on the Carrera 2.7 on page 162
This car also has intermittent wipers â€“ option code M652 â€“ which doesnâ€™t show up on the PPS (but Porsche made mistakes â€“ remember, humans were logging the data at the factory, and not always perfect â€“ I have old CoAs I obtained in the 90s and they miss options as well as not logging the gearbox numbers). the intermittent wipers could have been factory, dealer or later installed by a previous ownerâ€¦
The mirrors are incorrect for a 1975. The mirrors on this car were introduced for model year 1976 in single (driverâ€™s side) or dual mirrors. The switch is correct and in the right location for adjusting dual mirrors as on the 1976 cars. Again, this could have been dealer or later owner installed. This car would have come with a 1974/75 flag mirror either chrome if that trim was ordered, black or painted body colour, depending on timing, all are correct for 1975â€¦
The ducktail is incorrect, but the Carrera tail provided is the correct type with single large air vent like non spoiler engine covers (Porsche part number 911.512.010.07 which may be seen stamped on the left hand side of the inner steel frame or in the groove of the central support bar inside the tail, but not always)â€¦ This was originally introduced on the 1974 3.0 RS homologation car (not to be confused with Carrera 2.7) Also the front rubber lip spoiler is correct for a 1975 (incorrect for a 1974, although it is added later by some owners), and actually is beneficial to balancing the carâ€¦ I noted the PPS doesnâ€™t list the spoilers either â€“ sometimes they are, and sometimes they arenâ€™tâ€¦
Now â€“ my two cents opinion â€“ it looks like a nicely restored and unique colour combination carâ€¦ the tail is easy to change, the headlight washers are correct (opinion as to how they look is down to each individual), the mirrors harder, as they will require metal work and respray or touch up of the doors to be correctâ€¦ 
GLWTA!

### Doug's Take
The 997 Porsche 911 GT3 boasts a naturally aspirated Mezger 6-cylinder engine, a mandatory 6-speed manual transmission, and an analog driving experience. This GT3 is finished in classic Guards Red and touts some desirable features like the Sport Chrono Package and leather and Alcantara upholstery â€“ along with a number of great modifications intended to improve the look, sound, and driving experience. Plus, this GT3 comes with plenty of documented major services and a clean, accident-free Carfax report showing Western and Southern ownership since new â€“ and it's offered with the added thrill of no reserve!
### Highlights
THISâ€¦ is a 2010 Porsche 911 GT3, finished in Guards Red with a black interior.
â˜ This 911 features the desirable 6-speed manual transmission.
â˜ The attached Carfax vehicle history report shows no accidents or mileage discrepancies in this GT3â€™s past; it also shows that this GT3 has been registered in Southern and Western states since new.
â˜ A partial list of notable equipment reported by the seller includes the Sport Chrono Package, adjustable dampers, dry sump engine lubrication, a transmission oil cooler, full leather and Alcantara upholstery, and deviated stitching in Guards Red.
â˜ A full list of notable modifications reported by the seller is detailed below. Highlights include an Akrapovic titanium exhaust, 911 GT3 RS 4.0 clutch and flywheel, a Guard limited-slip differential, and 19-inch Apex wheels.
â˜ Porsche released the track-focused 997-generation GT3 in 2006 as the most aggressive normally-aspirated version of the 911 before the introduction of the more hardcore GT3 RS. It featured a 3.8-liter "Mezger" engine, lift-reducing aerodynamic body work, a revised version of Porsche Active Suspension Management System (PASM), and no rear seats. Armed with a close-ratio 6-speed manual transmission and a flat-6 engine that can rev up to 8,400 rpm, the 997.2 GT3 is still considered one of the most exciting road-legal sports cars money can buy.
â˜ Power comes from a Hans Mezger-designed naturally aspirated 3.8-liter flat-6, rated at 435 horsepower and 317 lb-ft of torque. Output is sent to the rear wheels via a 6-speed manual transmission.

### Porsche 718 vs 981 Comparison

Porsche 718 vs 981
Consider the 718 as a .2 to the 981 . Itâ€™s a evolution not a revolution the differences are all very similar to the 991 GT3 .1 and .2 scenario .
From my experience bearing in mind my 718 has only been out of running in a week or so .
Looks - 718 more modern looking gets more attention for sure
981- more old school Porsche looking
Engine - 718 - far smoother and 100% a quicker car in gear with more torque available through more of the Rev range . Cylinder deactivation is also fantastic when driving normally ie town or cruising mpg into high 30â€™s compared to low 20â€™s in 981 .
981 engine feels more gruff and exciting the 3.8 is a fantastic engine for a blast or day out . Throttle response is great in both
exhaust - 718 very muted with valves shut but just about right with them open and a very different deeper sound .
981 - simply fantastic as stock valves open or shut and more of a high pitched sound .
Handling - 718 definitely more composed and more planted with the newer hard ware and software . Canâ€™t feel itâ€™s any heavier than the 981 they feel the same .
981 - pin sharp turn in maybe a tad sharper than the 718 but not much again splitting hairs really .
Interior - 718 loooks similar but with the newer lay out of vents and chrono clock feels a tad more modern tech wise there really isnâ€™t any comparison as the 981 is very dated .
Few other things personal to me , I prefer the wheels on the 718 but prefer the front lip layout and design of the 981 because the 718 looks amazing but itâ€™s ridiculously low and long and scrapes on the most ridiculous of minor slopes . Both cars are incredible but for me personally I find the 718 more modern user friendly on a long distance which is where I use my cars most so for me I wouldnâ€™t go back to a 981 as itâ€™s more suited to a short blast or track day .
Either way youâ€™ll be happy as a pig in **** maybe watch Steve sutcliffs review of the 718 GT4 as I think he sums it up perfectly . The first GT4 was brilliant but the 718 is just that little bit faster and better at everything .
edit , and another point the 718 GT4 feels so different to the 718 Spyder . More aggressive and sharp . It really is quite bizarre considering they are so say the same car .
