The Zen Art of Customer Acquisition
# 
# Introduction
At OptiMonk, we have over 10 years of experience helping e-commerce site owners achieve success. Weâ€™ve gathered our best techniques for improving your customer acquisition and conversion rate. With a few simple steps and the help of OptiMonk, you can boost the efficiency of your website â€” and it only takes a few minutes to get started!
Weâ€™ve created a â€œPractical Guideâ€ to help you get the best results from OptiMonk. Here you can learn how to turn more visitors into buyers. Itâ€™s a straightforward guide that helps you understand the basics of conversion. We also teach you how to use newsletters to increase sales among your email list subscribers.
Weâ€™ve organized some of our favorite techniques into a set of â€œSimple and Effective Methods for Customer Acquisition.â€ The Basics section is light-hearted. It helps you understand customer acquisition strategies better, and have fun in the process. Smile! This is Zen and the art of e-commerce.
### Basics:
â˜ What is conversion?
â˜ A lot of people downloaded my coupons, so why didn't my sales grow?
â˜ What should I communicate to my subscribers?
â˜ How should I send my emails?
### Advanced Methods
â˜ Customer Acquisition Method #1: The JOKER Offer
â˜ Customer Acquisition Method #2: The Date Method
â˜ Customer Acquisition Method #3: The Fishermanâ€™s Method
# BasicsÂ 
### 1. What is conversion?
In the simplest terms, your conversion rate is the percentage of your website visitors who perform a certain action on your site. This action can be clicking on a link, downloading an e-book, or purchasing a product.
In OptiMonkâ€™s case, the conversion rate is the percentage of visitors who were presented with our popup and took the desired action. For example, a 6 percent OptiMonk conversion rate means that 6 out of 100 people who received our popup entered their contact information.
What we call a good conversion rate depends on many factors, mostly the type of conversion and your target audience. When the desired action is a purchase, we consider a conversion rate of 1 or 2 percent to be â€œgood.â€ When the desired action is downloading a coupon, the percentage is higher, usually between 2 and 4 percent. The rate can be even higher, depending on your offer.
### 2. A lot of people downloaded my coupons, but my sales didnâ€™t grow. What should I do with all my new newsletter subscribers?
Now that youâ€™ve built a large list of email subscribers with OptiMonk, the next step is to develop a strategy to best utilize your email list. A good email list is potentially very valuable, but itâ€™s not worth a penny without a good strategy that converts these subscribers to buyers.
When a visitor downloads your coupon or signs up for your email list, it means that he or she is closer to buying than those who did not sign up or download a coupon. However, this does not necessarily mean they will buy something right away. They might need more information or an explanation about what they can redeem with their coupon. They might just need a reminder that their coupon is about to expire.
OptiMonk helps you convert more visitors to buyers â€” visitors who would have otherwise left your site without providing their contact information. Now, they have signed up to be subscribers to your newsletter. In order to convert subscribers into customers, try the following steps:
â˜ First, thank them for subscribing or downloading your coupon. Fortunately, you can do this in the â€œthank youâ€ popup. Still, it is a good idea to say â€œthank youâ€ again in the confirmation e-mail.
â˜ A few days after they sign up, send coupon owners an email explaining how to redeem the coupon. If you have any kind of discounts or other offers, include them in this email.
â˜ Next, send a couple of reminder emails. Send the first one halfway between the sign up date and the expiration date; send another a few days before the expiration date. Call upon them to use their coupons because they are about to expire.
### 3.Â What should I communicate to my subscribers?
The first thing to remember is that your subscribers did sign up for your newsletter or download your coupon. Therefore, they are interested in your business. Feel free to communicate to them anything related to your business. Naturally, you should not write a whole letter about every little matter.
Imagine that you operate out of a physical store instead of an e-commerce site. What would you be willing to share with those who wandered into your store? What would you tell current clients?Â Think up a few topics that you would tell people who visited your imaginary store.
Perhaps you DO have a physical store. If so, you might have some ideas already. Take these ideas and organize them into a newsletter to your subscribers. You can take a personal approach to speaking to your clients, and reach a wider audience! Here are a few sample topics to consider:
â˜ A new product/product line in your store
â˜ A new team member youâ€™ve recently hired
â˜ Fun new ways other customers use your product
â˜ Current discounts
â˜ Special discounts only for subscribers
â˜ Recent news related to your business or industry
â˜ A local event or volunteer group your business supports
You can write about a wide range of topics connected to your site or store on any level. Your writing should be personal and full of life, and your readers should love it. However (and this is important), it shouldnâ€™t always be about whatâ€™s on sale that week. Be creative. Personalize your site or store with your own experiences. Send out your newsletters on a set schedule. Whether it is once a week, once every two weeks, or once a month, set a schedule and stick to it. That way, your most dedicated subscribers come to anticipate your newsletter.
### 4.Â How should I send my emails?
One thing you should keep in mind when choosing an email newsletter platform is to make sure it has the ability to send autoresponders or automated newsletters to new subscribers. This is a must-have for an email newsletter platform. Popular services such as MailChimp and Constant Contact include this feature.
Remember, raising your customersâ€™ attention with OptiMonk is the first step.
You have to keep their attention level high with consistent communication. All the tools are available for you. By following the steps in the practical guide above and using the methods we describe below, you can achieve results. Itâ€™s a lot easier than you think!. Writing the auto responders will only take a few afternoons, and once that is done, the system is automatic. In the case of the newsletters, you only have to schedule a few hours for the task, and this decreases over time. As you become more experienced, youâ€™ll learn to quickly write fun and personal messages that engage your audience.
# Advanced Methods
### 5.Â Customer Acquisition Method #1: The JOKER Offer
The first customer acquisition method is â€œThe JOKER offer.â€ Use this method when standard offers fail to get results.
About the Method:
In cards, the JOKER is the card that can replace anything, that fits everywhere. For example, if you need a 7 of clubs to make a straight flush, the JOKER can replace it. In this way, the JOKER is the most valuable card.
Almost certainly, you have a JOKER card in your company deckâ€”a product or an offer that would do well for basically everybody, and which you can use when your standard offers fail.
This can be a special product, which you make available at a great price. It can be any product that you sell at a discount, or even a free study that interests most of your clients.
The goal is to get ALL of your visitors to see this JOKER offer, but especially those who did not convert (i.e., those unconvinced by your standard offer). The easiest way is to intrigue them before they leave your site with a popup like this:
This way, all of your visitors see the JOKER offer, and many of themâ€”depending on the efficiency of the offerâ€”will convert into customers.
All this requires only a few minutes to set up in your OptiMonk account. Log inÂ orÂ sign up here!
### 6. Customer Acquisition Method #2: The Date Method
When youâ€™re selling to someone, itâ€™s a lot like a courtship. Therefore, our second suggested technique is â€œThe Date Method.â€ This method employs a sensitive approach to win your customerâ€™s hearts.
About the Method:
Did you know that there is a huge resemblance between customer acquisition and courtship? You use similar techniques to impress a customer as those you use to court the woman or man of your dreams. Surprised? Let me explain.
Suppose that you meet a girl, and you fall in love with her at first sight. Whatâ€™s the best strategy to court her?
1. You walk right up to her and say, â€œHi, my name is XY. I really like you, and I would like you to marry me!â€
2. You approach her and introduce yourself. You chat a little, and you invite her for a drink. If all goes well, you ask her out on a date. Then you ask her out on a second date and a third. If the dates go well, you both get to know and trust each other. Only then do you ask her to make a commitment.
Clearly, technique number 1 is probably not going work. Itâ€™s awfully sudden. Technique number 2 is clearly the better choice.
Customers feel the same way about this. They donâ€™t like a strong up-front approach; they hate when someone tries to sell them a product by any means. Unfortunately, most companies try to sell this way. They want to buyer to buy at first sight. Buy now! Buy now!
Just as itâ€™s more effective to ask for a girlâ€™s phone number than for her hand in marriage when youâ€™ve just met, it is more practical to ask for the prospectâ€™s email address during the first round. Get visitors to subscribe to your newsletter with an offer like this:
Then, after they give you their email address, you can send them valuable and useful materials. This helps them get to know you better, and you can build trust. Then, from time to time, you can approach them with an offer.
You can set this all up in a couple of minutes in your OptiMonk account! Login to your account or sign up here. Drop a line to support@optimonk.com and weâ€™ll help you get started courting your customers today!
### 7. Customer Acquisition Method #3: The Fishermanâ€™s Method
Our third suggestion is â€œThe Fishermanâ€™s Method.â€ The key to successful fishing is the bait. Check out this simple method to â€œcatchâ€ more customers.
About the Method:
How does fishing work? The fisherman throws a bucket into the water, waits until the fish swims into it, and when the bucket is full, he pulls it out from the water? Well, not really.
One key to successful fishing is the bait: you have to draw the fish to your area and get them to bite on your hook.
Often, bait is the key to successful customer acquisition, as well. Just because you have a newsletter subscription or contact form on your site does not mean that visitors will actually purchase, or â€œjump into the bucket.â€
However, if you have good bait that your customers find valuable â€“ like a fish values a worm â€“ and which you can provide relatively cheaply or for free, then your customers have an incentive to bite on the hook.
The bait can be a coupon like this:
Or a gift package:

### A Tax That Could Fix Big Tech 
**Type:** Article | **Publisher:** NYT | **Summary:** Putting a levy on targeted ad revenue would give Facebook and Google a real incentive to change their dangerous business models. | **Publishing/Release Date:** 2019-09-06 | **Link:** https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/06/opinion/tax-facebook-google.html | **Status:** Ready to Start | **Author:** Paul Romer

It is the job of government to prevent a tragedy of the commons. That includes the commons of shared values and norms on which democracy depends. The dominant digital platform companies, including Facebook and Google, make their profits using business models that erode this commons. They have created a haven for dangerous misinformation and hate speech that has undermined trust in democratic institutions. And it is troubling when so much information is controlled by so few companies.
What is the best way to protect and restore this public commons? Most of the proposals to change platform companies rely on either antitrust law or regulatory action. I propose a different solution. Instead of banning the current business model â€” in which platform companies harvest user information to sell targeted digital ads â€” new legislation could establish a tax that would encourage platform companies to shift toward a healthier, more traditional model.
The tax that I propose would be applied to revenue from sales of targeted digital ads, which are the key to the operation of Facebook, Google and the like. At the federal level, Congress could add it as a surcharge to the corporate income tax. At the state level, a legislature could adopt it as a type of sales tax on the revenue a company collects for displaying ads to residents of the state.
There are several advantages to using tax legislation, rather than antitrust law or regulation, as a strategy. Senator Elizabeth Warren, for example, has called for breaking up big tech companies. But the antitrust remedies that Ms. Warren and other policy experts are suggesting ask prosecutors and judges to make policy decisions best left to legislatures. Existing antitrust law in the United States addresses mainly the harm from price gouging, not the other kinds of harm caused by these platforms, such as stifling innovation and undermining the institutions of democracy.
Our digital platforms may not be too big to fail. But they are too big to trust and â€” despite the call by Mark Zuckerberg, Facebookâ€™s chief executive, for new legislation and regulation â€” may already be too big to regulate. Powerful companies can capture or undermine a regulator. The Interstate Commerce Commission, for example, established in the 19th century, ended up serving the interests of the rail and trucking industry instead of the public. And the recent crashes of two Boeing airplanes have raised serious concern that the Federal Aviation Administration, which has a long history as an effective regulator, has been neutered by the aviation industry.
Of course, companies are incredibly clever about avoiding taxes. But in this case, thatâ€™s a good thing for all of us. This tax would spur their creativity. Ad-driven platform companies could avoid the tax entirely by switching to the business model that many digital companies already offer: an ad-free subscription. Under this model, consumers know what they give up, and the success of the business would not hinge on tracking customers with ever more sophisticated surveillance techniques. A company could succeed the old-fashioned way: by delivering a service that is worth more than it costs.
Some corporations will persist with the targeted ad model if it yields more profit, even after paying the tax. To limit the size of those businesses, the tax could be progressive, with higher rates for larger companies. This would have the added benefit of creating a corporate version of a marriage penalty. When two companies combine, their total tax bill would go up.
A progressive digital ad revenue tax would also make sure that dominant social media platforms bear the brunt of the tax. Thatâ€™s important: It makes it easier for new companies to enter the market, so consumers will have more choices. A new entrant would also be less likely to be acquired if thereâ€™s a tax penalty. A large company might reduce its tax bill by breaking itself into several smaller companies. It would be up to Congress or state legislatures to decide where to place the thresholds at which higher tax rates kick in.
If these measures arenâ€™t enough, Congress has the power to create new laws that address specific problems. It could follow the Wall Street reforms of Dodd-Frank and define â€œsystemically important social media platformsâ€ that would be required to meet stringent transparency standards or be subject to a â€œfairness doctrineâ€ for balanced reporting, similar to what broadcasters once faced.
From the very beginning, Americans have refused to tolerate unchecked power. We must now press our legislators to protect us from the unchecked power of dominant digital platforms. The bigger they get and the more they know, the greater the threat to our social and political way of life.
Paul Romer, a recipient of the 2018 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, advised the Department of Justice in its antitrust case against Microsoft.
The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. Weâ€™d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And hereâ€™s our email: letters@nytimes.com.
Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook, Twitter (@NYTopinion) and Instagram.

### Jane Eyre and the Invention of Self
**Score /5:** â­ï¸â­ï¸ | **Type:** Essay Resource | **Publisher:** The Atlantic | **Publishing/Release Date:** 2016-09-03 | **Link:** https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/03/how-jane-eyre-created-the-modern-self/460461/ | **Status:** Reading | **Author:** Karen Swallow Prior

Consider the selfie. By now, itâ€™s a fairly mundane artistic tradition, even afterÂ aprofusionÂ of thinkpiecesÂ have wrestled withÂ its rise thanks to the so-calledÂ Me Generationâ€™s â€œobsessionâ€ with social media. Anyone in possession of a cheap camera phone or laptop can take a picture of themselves, edit it (or not), and share it with the world in a matter or seconds.
But before theÂ selfieÂ came â€œthe self,â€ or the fairly modern concept of the independent â€œindividual.â€ The now-ubiquitous selfie expresses in miniature the seismic conceptual shift that came about centuries ago, spurred in part by advances in printing technology and new ways of thinking in philosophy. Itâ€™s not that the self didnâ€™t exist in pre-modern cultures: Rather, the emphasis the Protestant Reformation in the 16th century placed on personal will, conscience, and understandingâ€”rather than tradition and authorityâ€”in matters of faith spilled over the bounds of religious experience into all of life. Perhaps the first novel to best express the modern idea of the self wasÂ Jane Eyre, written in 1847 by Charlotte BrontÃ«, born 200 years ago this year.
Those who rememberÂ Jane EyreÂ solely as required reading in high-school English class likely recall most vividly its over-the-top Gothic tropes: a childhood banishment to a death-haunted room, a mysterious presence in the attic, a Byronic hero, and a cold mansion going up in flames. Itâ€™s more seemingly the stuff of Lifetime television, not revolutions. But as unbelievable as many of the events of the novel are, even today, BrontÃ«â€™s biggest accomplishment wasnâ€™t in plot devices. It was the narrative voice of Janeâ€”who so openly expressed her desire for identity, definition, meaning, and agencyâ€”that rang powerfully true to its 19th-century audience. In fact, many early readers mistakenly believedÂ Jane EyreÂ was a true account (in a clever marketing scheme, the novel was subtitled, â€œAn Autobiographyâ€), perhaps a validation of her characterâ€™s authenticity.
The way that novels paid attention to the particularities of human experience (rather than the universals of the older epics and romances) made them the ideal vehicle to shape how readers understood the modern individual. The rise of the literary form was made possible by the technology of the printing press, the print culture that followed, and the widening literacy that was cultivated for centuries untilÂ Jane Eyreâ€™s publication. The novel seemed perfectly designed to tell BrontÃ«â€™s first-person narrative of a destitute orphan girl searching for a secure identityâ€”first among an unloving family, then an austere charity school, and finally with the wealthy but unattainable employer she loves. Unable to find her sense of self through others, Jane makes the surprising decision to turnÂ inward.
The broader cultural implications of the storyâ€”its insistence on the value of conscience and willâ€”were such thatÂ one critic frettedÂ some years after its publication that the â€œmost alarming revolution of modern times has followed the invasion ofÂ Jane Eyre.â€ Before the Reformation and the Enlightenment that followed, before Rene Descartesâ€™sÂ cogito ergo sumÂ (â€œI think, therefore I amâ€), when the sources of authority were external and objective, the aspects of the self so central to todayâ€™s understanding mattered little because they didnâ€™t really affect the course of an individualâ€™s life. The Reformation empowered believers to read and interpret the scriptures for themselves, rather than relying on the help of clergy; by extension, this seemed to give people permission to read and interpret their own interior world.
To be sure, early novelists before BrontÃ« such as Frances Burney, Daniel Defoe, Samuel Richardson, and Mary Shelley contributed to the formâ€™s developing art of the first-person narrator. But these authors used the contrivances of edited letters or memoirs, devices that tended toward underdeveloped characters, episodic plots, and a general sense of artificialityâ€”even when the stories were presented not as fiction but â€œhistories.â€ No earlier novelist had provided a voice so seemingly pure, so fully belonging to the character, as BrontÃ«. She developed her art alongside her sisters, the novelists Anne and Emily (all of them publishing under gender-neutral pseudonyms), but it was Charlotte whose work best captured the sense of the modern individual. Anne BrontÃ«â€™s novelsÂ Agnes GreyÂ andÂ The Tenant of Wildfell HallÂ contributed to the novelâ€™s ability to offer social commentary and criticism, while the Romantic sensibilities of Emily BrontÃ«â€™sÂ Wuthering HeightsÂ explored how the â€œother,â€ in the form of the dark, unpredictable Heathcliff, can threaten the integrity of the self.
One of the greatest testimonies to BrontÃ«â€™s accomplishment came from Virginia Woolf, a modernist pioneer who represents a world far removed from that of Bronteâ€™s Victorianism. â€œAs we openÂ Jane EyreÂ once more,â€ a doubting Woolf wrote inÂ The Common Reader,Â â€œwe cannot stifle the suspicion that we shall find her world of imagination as antiquated, mid-Victorian, and out of date as the parsonage on the moor, a place only to be visited by the curious, only preserved by the pious.â€ Woolf continues, â€œSo we openÂ Jane Eyre;Â and in two pages every doubt is swept clean from our minds.â€ There is nothing of the book, Woolf declares, â€œexcept Jane Eyre.â€ Janeâ€™s voice is the source of the power the book has to absorb the reader completely into her world. Woolf explains how BrontÃ«Â depicts:
> â€¦ an overpowering personality, so that, as we say in real life, they have only to open the door to make themselves felt. There is in them some untamed ferocity perpetually at war with the accepted order of things which makes them desire to create instantly rather than to observe patiently.
It is exactly this willingnessâ€”desire, evenâ€”to be â€œat war with the accepted order of thingsâ€ that characterizes the modern self. While we now take such a sense for granted, it was, as BrontÃ«â€™s contemporaries rightly understood, radical in her day. More disturbing to BrontÃ«â€™s Victorian readers than the sheer sensuality of the story and Janeâ€™s deep passion was â€œthe heroineâ€™s refusal to submit to her social destiny,â€ as the literary critic Sandra M. GilbertÂ explains. Indeed, oneÂ contemporary reviewÂ complained, â€œIt is true Jane does right, and exerts great moral strength,â€ but the critic continues that â€œit is the strength of a mere heathen mind which is a law unto itself.â€ In presenting such a character, the reviewer worries, BrontÃ« has â€œoverthrown authorityâ€ and cultivated â€œrebellion.â€ And in a way they were right: â€œI resisted all the way,â€ Jane says as she is dragged by her cruel aunt toward banishment in the bedroom where her late uncle died. This sentence,Â Joyce Carol Oates argues, serves as the theme of Janeâ€™s whole story.
But Janeâ€™s resistance is not the empty rebellion of nihilism or self-absorption (consider how current practitioners of â€œselfie cultureâ€ frequentlyÂ weather accusationsÂ of narcissism). Rather, her quest for her true self peels back the stiff layers of conventionality in order to discoverÂ genuineÂ morality and faith. As BrontÃ« explains in theÂ prefaceÂ to the novelâ€™s second edition (a preface necessitated by the moral outrage that followed the novelâ€™s publication),
> Conventionality is not morality. Self-righteousness is not religion. To attack the first is not to assail the last â€¦ These things and deeds are diametrically opposed: they are as distinct as is vice from virtue. Men too often confound them: they should not be confounded: appearance should not be mistaken for truth; narrow human doctrines, that only tend to elate and magnify a few, should not be substituted for the world.
In aÂ letterÂ to a friend, Bronte responded to her criticsâ€™ objections by declaring, â€œUnless I have the courage to use the language of Truth in preference to the jargon of Conventionality, I ought to be silent ...â€
The refusal of such a woman, who lived in such a time, to be silent created a new mold for the selfâ€”one apparent not only in todayâ€™s Instagram photos, but also more importantly in the collective modern sense that a personâ€™s inner life can allow her to effect change from the inside out.

# Research Race: Safety Not Guaranteed vs Stanley
## Competitive Analysis of Parallel Research Outputs

**Generated:** 2026-01-30  
**Topics:** (1) Clawdbot Skills Framework, (2) macOS CLI Framework  
**Our team (SNG):** 2 documents, 2,247 lines total  
**Stanley:** 6 documents, 2,430 lines total  

---

## 1. SKILLS FRAMEWORK COMPARISON

### What We Have

**Single unified doc** (`skills-framework.md`, 1,117 lines):
- Architecture diagram (how skills flow from folder â†’ system prompt â†’ agent)
- Complete SKILL.md frontmatter spec (every field, types, constraints)
- All 6 metadata install spec types with JSON examples (brew, cask, node, go, uv, download)
- 6 interface patterns with frequency percentages (CLI Wrapper 70%, Script Runner 15%, API Integration 10%, Native Bridge 5%, Built-in Tool Teaching 3%, Agent Orchestrator 2%)
- Top 50 skills catalog organized by category (7 categories, 50 entries)
- 8 extracted code/convention patterns (`{baseDir}`, `MEDIA:`, `--json`, references/, etc.)
- 4 complete framework templates (CLI wrapper, Script runner, API integration, Native bridge)
- 10 best practices from analysis
- 8 common pitfalls with âŒ/âœ… code diffs
- Full security section (threat model, safe vs risky table, sandboxing guide)
- Skills vs Plugins comparison with decision tree
- 3 appendices (token formula, config reference, quick reference card)

### What Stanley Has

**Three specialized docs** (819 lines total):

1. **`skill-framework.md`** (382 lines) â€” ClawdHub registry research:
   - Complete scan of all 42 ClawdHub skills with download counts, star ratings, version counts, tags
   - 4 structure categories from real hub data (SKILL.md only ~50%, +Scripts ~25%, +References ~15%, Multi-component ~10%)

   - Hub API structure documentation

2. **`skill-docs.md`** (269 lines) â€” Official documentation distillation:
   - Complete skill lifecycle (Create â†’ Test â†’ Publish â†’ Install â†’ Use â†’ Update)
   - Matching mechanism: "matching is done by the LLM itself" â€” no separate engine
   - Full gating table
   - `clawdbot security audit --deep` command
   - Remote macOS nodes pattern (Linux gateway + macOS node)
   - `command-dispatch`, `command-tool`, `command-arg-mode` frontmatter keys

3. **`skill-structure.md`** (168 lines) â€” Installed skill analysis:
   - 11 actual skills analyzed with effectiveness ratings (âœ… Excellent / âš ï¸ Mixed)
   - 4 skill archetypes: Pure Knowledge, Script Wrapper, Workflow Process, Product Integration
   - Anti-patterns with specific offenders (ringbot = marketing bloat, github = redundant knowledge)
   - Configuration pattern taxonomy (5 types)

---

### What We Covered That Stanley Missed

| Our Unique Coverage | Why It Matters |
|---|---|
| **All 6 metadata install spec types** with JSON examples (brew, cask, node, go, uv, download) | Can't build a distributable skill without these |
| **6 interface patterns with percentages** (CLI Wrapper 70%, Script Runner 15%, etc.) | Tells you what pattern to pick for your use case |
| **Top 50 skills catalog** (vs Stanley's 42 ClawdHub-only) | We include bundled skills Stanley never saw |
| **4 complete copy-paste framework templates** | Stanley describes patterns but never gives full templates |
| **Skills vs Plugins decision tree** | Critical architectural choice Stanley doesn't address |
| **Security threat model** (what a malicious skill CAN do) | Stanley lists red flags but not the actual attack vectors |
| **Token impact formula** (`195 + Î£(97 + len(name) + len(desc) + len(loc))`) | Quantitative, not just qualitative |
| **Common pitfalls with code diffs** (8 specific âŒâ†’âœ… pairs) | Immediately prevents mistakes |
| **Quick Reference Card** (visual cheatsheet) | At-a-glance build guide |

### What Stanley Covered That We Missed

| Stanley's Unique Coverage | Why It Matters |

| **Overall** | **Safety Not Guaranteed** | 62-38 | More visionary, more complete, more novel insights |

### Why SNG Won

1. **Novel insights that don't exist elsewhere**: Photos ML metadata mining, Knowledge DB for context-aware AI, CoreML from CLI â€” these aren't in any blog post or documentation. Stanley's research is thorough but doesn't surface anything truly new.

2. **Completeness as reference material**: Both our docs can stand alone as build guides. You can construct a skill or a macOS CLI tool from scratch using only our documents. Stanley's docs require combining 3 files and still lack templates.

3. **Strategic vision**: The 3-tier automation roadmap (18 concepts), the Approach-by-App matrix, the Skills vs Plugins decision tree â€” these are strategic thinking tools, not just research summaries.

4. **Architecture diagrams**: Visual ASCII diagrams for automation channels, skill loading flow, decision trees. Stanley uses tables but no architectural diagrams.

### Why Stanley Was Still Strong

1. **Empirical grounding**: ClawdHub download stats, real skill effectiveness ratings, build performance benchmarks â€” Stanley works with data, not assumptions.

2. **Engineering practicality**: The 7 AI code generation gotchas, `-swift-version 5` flag, "skip ArgumentParser" recommendation, pre-built tool library architecture â€” these save real engineering time.

3. **Ecosystem awareness**: 30+ Homebrew tools cataloged, MCP integration pattern discovered, `command-dispatch` frontmatter found. Stanley reads the actual documentation and codebase more carefully.

4. **AI reliability ratings**: â­ ratings for each approach tell you what an AI agent can actually execute reliably. We never scored our approaches.

### What Each Can Learn From the Other

**SNG should adopt from Stanley:**
- Add MCP as a 7th skill interface pattern
- Include build performance benchmarks in Swift recommendations

- Use `-swift-version 5` in all Swift templates

**Stanley should adopt from SNG:**

- Complete copy-paste skill templates (not just descriptions)

- Architecture diagrams for visual communication

# Secure Identity Verification â€” Future Project
> Created: 2026-01-29
> Status: Brainstorm / Low Priority
> Requested by: Matt (Shiv present)

## Goal
Create a secure, novel verification system so that:
- Matt can confirm he's talking to the real Stanley (and vice versa)
- Matt can confirm he's talking to the real Shiv's AI (and vice versa)
- The two AIs can verify each other's identity
- Verification should NOT be something that can be spoofed over text
- Should survive session resets, compaction, etc.

## Constraints
- Can't rely on text-based shared secrets alone (too easy to intercept/replay)
- Needs to work across iMessage, Telegram, SSH
- Should be "unique and novel" â€” not just passwords
- Must be persistent (stored in memory files, not session context)

## Initial Ideas to Brainstorm
- Rotating challenge-response codes (crypto-signed)
- Behavioral verification (ask something only the real agent would know from private memory)
- Multi-channel verification (confirm on channel A what was said on channel B)
- Time-based one-time codes (TOTP-style)
- Cryptographic key pairs â€” each agent has a private key, shares public key
- "Canary" phrases embedded in memory that change on a schedule
- Hardware-bound identity (tied to Mac mini's secure enclave?)

## Next Steps
- [ ] Both AIs brainstorm during idle cron time
- [ ] Share proposals in group thread when ready
- [ ] Matt reviews and picks approach
- [ ] Implement after SSH access is stable

# Clawdbot Skills â€” Documentation Analysis

> Generated 2026-01-29 from local docs (`/opt/homebrew/lib/node_modules/clawdbot/docs/`) and web sources.

## 1. What Is a Skill?

A skill is a **directory containing a `SKILL.md`** file with YAML frontmatter and instructions. It follows the [AgentSkills](https://agentskills.io) spec. Skills teach the agent how to use tools â€” they're injected into the system prompt as compact XML so the LLM knows what's available.

### Minimum `SKILL.md`

```markdown
---
name: my-skill
description: One-line description of what this skill does.
---

# My Skill

Instructions the agent uses to invoke the tool...
```

### Optional Frontmatter Keys

| Key | Type | Default | Purpose |
|-----|------|---------|---------|
| `name` | string | required | Skill identifier |
| `description` | string | required | Used for matching to user requests |
| `homepage` | string | â€” | URL shown in macOS Skills UI |
| `metadata` | JSON string | â€” | Gating rules, install specs, emoji, etc. |
| `user-invocable` | bool | `true` | Expose as user slash command |
| `disable-model-invocation` | bool | `false` | Exclude from model prompt (still available via slash) |
| `command-dispatch` | string | â€” | Set to `tool` to bypass model and call tool directly |
| `command-tool` | string | â€” | Tool name for direct dispatch |
| `command-arg-mode` | string | `raw` | Arg passing mode for tool dispatch |

### Metadata Block (Single-Line JSON)

```json
{"clawdbot":{"emoji":"â™Šï¸","os":["darwin"],"always":true,"requires":{"bins":["mytool"],"anyBins":["a","b"],"env":["MY_API_KEY"],"config":["browser.enabled"]},"primaryEnv":"MY_API_KEY","install":[{"id":"brew","kind":"brew","formula":"mytool","bins":["mytool"],"label":"Install mytool (brew)"}]}}
```

## 2. Skill Lifecycle

### Create
1. Create a directory (e.g., `skills/my-skill/`)
2. Write a `SKILL.md` with frontmatter (`name`, `description`) and instructions
3. Optionally add supporting text files in the same directory
4. Use `{baseDir}` in instructions to reference the skill folder path

### Test
- Place in `<workspace>/skills/` â€” highest precedence, overrides everything
- Skills watcher auto-refreshes on `SKILL.md` changes (no restart needed)
- New session picks up changes; mid-session hot-reload also works
- Verify with the macOS Skills UI or gateway `skills.status` RPC

### Publish (via ClawdHub)
```bash
clawdhub publish ./skills/my-skill \
  --slug my-skill \
  --name "My Skill" \
  --version 1.0.0 \
  --tags latest
```
Or batch publish:
```bash
clawdhub sync --all
```

### Install
```bash
clawdhub install <skill-slug>
# Or specific version:
clawdhub install <skill-slug> --version 2.0.0
```
Installs into `./skills` by default. Tracked in `.clawdhub/lock.json`.

### Use
- Agent automatically sees eligible skills in its system prompt
- Skills are matched to user requests via their `description` field
- Users can also invoke via slash commands if `user-invocable: true`

### Update
```bash
clawdhub update <slug>
clawdhub update --all
```

## 3. Skill Loading & Precedence

Skills load from **three locations** (highest to lowest precedence):

1. **Workspace skills**: `<workspace>/skills/` â€” per-agent, highest priority
2. **Managed/local skills**: `~/.clawdbot/skills/` â€” shared across all agents
3. **Bundled skills**: shipped with the npm package or Clawdbot.app

Additional sources:
- `skills.load.extraDirs` in config (lowest precedence)
- Plugin-shipped skills (via `clawdbot.plugin.json`)

**Name conflicts**: workspace wins â†’ managed/local â†’ bundled.

**Session snapshot**: Eligible skills are snapshotted at session start and reused. Changes take effect on next session (or via hot-reload if watcher is enabled).

## 4. How Skills Are Matched to User Requests

Clawdbot injects eligible skills into the **system prompt** as compact XML:
```xml
<skill><name>my-skill</name><description>Do something useful</description><location>/path/to/skill</location></skill>
```

**Matching is done by the LLM itself** â€” the model reads the skill names, descriptions, and instructions, then decides which skill to invoke based on the user's natural language request. There is no separate matching engine; the `description` field is critical for discoverability.

**ClawdHub search** uses embeddings (vector search) for finding skills by plain language, not just keywords.

### Token Cost Per Skill
- Base overhead (â‰¥1 skill): 195 characters
- Per skill: ~97 chars + length of name + description + location
- Rough estimate: ~24 tokens per skill (plus your field lengths)

## 5. Gating (Load-Time Filters)

Skills are filtered **before** they reach the prompt:

| Gate | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `always: true` | Skip all other gates, always include |
| `os` | Platform filter (`darwin`, `linux`, `win32`) |
| `requires.bins` | All listed binaries must exist on PATH |
| `requires.anyBins` | At least one binary must exist |
| `requires.env` | Env vars must exist (or be provided in config) |
| `requires.config` | Config paths in `clawdbot.json` must be truthy |
| `enabled: false` | Explicitly disabled in config |
| `allowBundled` | Allowlist for bundled skills only |

If no `metadata.clawdbot` is present, the skill is always eligible (unless disabled).

## 6. Configuration (`clawdbot.json`)

```json5
{
  skills: {
    allowBundled: ["gemini", "peekaboo"],  // restrict which bundled skills load
    load: {
      extraDirs: ["~/extra-skills"],        // additional scan directories
      watch: true,                          // auto-refresh on changes
      watchDebounceMs: 250
    },
    install: {
      preferBrew: true,
      nodeManager: "npm"                    // npm | pnpm | yarn | bun
    },
    entries: {
      "my-skill": {
        enabled: true,
        apiKey: "KEY_HERE",                 // maps to primaryEnv
        env: { MY_API_KEY: "KEY_HERE" },    // injected per agent run
        config: { endpoint: "https://..." } // custom per-skill config
      }
    }
  }
}
```

### Environment Injection
- `env` values injected **only if** not already set in process
- Scoped to agent run, not global shell
- Original environment restored after run ends
- In sandboxed mode, skill env applies to **host** only (use `sandbox.docker.env` for containers)

## 7. Security Considerations

### What a Skill CAN Do
- Provide instructions that the LLM follows (tool usage patterns, CLI commands)
- Reference binaries on the host system
- Receive injected environment variables (API keys, secrets)
- Be invoked as slash commands
- Ship supporting scripts/files in its directory

### What a Skill Should NOT Do
- **Contain untrusted code** â€” skills are injected into prompts; treat as trusted
- **Expose secrets in prompts/logs** â€” use `env`/`apiKey` config, not hardcoded values
- **Skip sandboxing for risky tools** â€” prefer sandboxed runs for untrusted inputs
- **Use `--yolo` or equivalent bypass flags** â€” safety-critical operations need guardrails

### Security Best Practices (from docs)
1. **Read third-party skills before enabling** â€” treat them as trusted code
2. **Prefer sandboxed runs** for untrusted inputs and risky tools
3. **Use `skills.entries.*.env`** for secrets, not inline in SKILL.md
4. **Use `allowBundled`** to restrict which bundled skills load
5. **Run `clawdbot security audit`** regularly, especially after adding skills
6. **Sandboxed skills need special handling**: bins must exist inside the container; use `setupCommand` to install
7. **Keep secrets out of prompts and logs** â€” `env` and `apiKey` inject into host process only

### Threat Model Notes
- Skills run with the same privileges as the agent
- A malicious skill description could influence LLM behavior (prompt injection surface)
- Plugin-shipped skills run in-process with the Gateway â€” treat plugins as fully trusted
- `clawdbot security audit --deep` checks for common misconfigurations

## 8. ClawdHub â€” Public Skills Registry

**Site**: [clawdhub.com](https://clawdhub.com)

### Features
- Public browsing and search (embedding-based vector search)
- Semver versioning with changelogs and tags
- Download as zip per version
- Stars and comments
- Moderation hooks

### Publishing Metadata Required
- **slug**: URL-safe identifier
- **name**: Display name
- **version**: Semver (e.g., `1.0.0`)
- **changelog**: Text (can be empty)
- **tags**: Comma-separated (default: `latest`)

### CLI Quick Reference
```bash
clawdhub login                    # Auth (browser flow)
clawdhub search "query"           # Semantic search
clawdhub install <slug>           # Install skill
clawdhub update --all             # Update all
clawdhub publish <path> --slug x  # Publish
clawdhub sync --all               # Batch publish
clawdhub list                     # Show installed (from lock.json)
clawdhub delete <slug> --yes      # Remove (owner/admin)
```

## 9. Best Practices Summary

### Writing Skills
1. **Clear, specific descriptions** â€” this is how the LLM finds your skill
2. **Single-line metadata JSON** â€” the parser requires it
3. **Use `{baseDir}`** to reference skill directory paths
4. **Gate appropriately** â€” declare required bins, env vars, and config
5. **Provide install specs** for easy setup (brew/node/go/uv/download)
6. **Keep instructions concise** â€” every character costs tokens in the prompt

### Managing Skills
1. **Workspace skills for dev/testing** (highest precedence, easy to iterate)
2. **Managed skills for sharing** across agents on the same machine
3. **Use `allowBundled`** to control noise from bundled skills you don't need
4. **Enable the watcher** for hot-reload during development
5. **Use ClawdHub** for backup, sharing, and discovery

### Plugins + Skills
- Plugins can ship skills via their manifest (`clawdbot.plugin.json`)
- Plugin skills follow the same precedence rules
- Gate plugin skills via `metadata.clawdbot.requires.config`

## 10. Example Bundled Skills (for reference)

| Skill | Description | Gates |
|-------|-------------|-------|
| `gemini` | Gemini CLI for Q&A, summaries, generation | bins: `gemini` |
| `peekaboo` | macOS UI capture and automation | os: darwin, bins: `peekaboo` |
| `spotify-player` | Spotify playback control | (check SKILL.md) |
| `summarize` | Text summarization | bins: `summarize` |
| `discord` | Discord-specific interactions | (check SKILL.md) |
| `coding-agent` | Code assistance | (check SKILL.md) |

## 11. Remote macOS Nodes (Linux Gateway)

If the Gateway runs on Linux but a macOS node is connected with `system.run` allowed, Clawdbot can treat macOS-only skills as eligible when required binaries are present on that node. The agent executes those skills via `nodes.run`. If the node disconnects, skills remain visible but invocations may fail.

---

*Sources: `/opt/homebrew/lib/node_modules/clawdbot/docs/tools/skills.md`, `skills-config.md`, `clawdhub.md`, `platforms/mac/skills.md`, `plugin.md`, `gateway/security.md`, `docs.clawd.bot/tools/skills`*

## 2. File Structure Patterns

### 2.1 Required File: SKILL.md
**Every single skill has a `SKILL.md`** â€” this is the core definition file. It's the only mandatory file.

### 2.2 Common Directory Layout

```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md              # REQUIRED â€” main skill definition (always present)
â”œâ”€â”€ README.md             # Optional â€” user-facing docs (some skills have both)
â”œâ”€â”€ skill.json            # Rare â€” structured metadata (seen in dashboard)
â”œâ”€â”€ setup.sh              # Rare â€” installation script
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/              # Common â€” executable scripts
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ *.py              # Python scripts (most common)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ *.mjs             # Node.js scripts
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ *.sh              # Shell scripts
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ package.json      # Node dependencies
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ package-lock.json # Lockfile
â”œâ”€â”€ assets/               # Common â€” templates, static files
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ *.md / *.txt      # Template files, monograms, etc.
â”œâ”€â”€ references/           # Used by complex skills
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ *.md              # Reference documentation
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ examples/         # Sample data (JSON, etc.)
â”œâ”€â”€ agents/               # Used by multi-agent skills (promptify)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ *.md              # Sub-agent definitions
â”œâ”€â”€ commands/             # Used by command-based skills (promptify)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ *.md              # Command documentation
â”œâ”€â”€ profiles/             # Used by persona skills (multiple-personas)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ persona-name/
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ SOUL.md
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ PERSONALITY.md
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ MEMORY.md
â””â”€â”€ src/                  # Used by app-type skills (dashboard)
    â”œâ”€â”€ app.py
    â”œâ”€â”€ static/
    â””â”€â”€ templates/
```

### 2.3 Structure Categories Observed

**Category A: SKILL.md Only (Minimalist)**
- ~50% of skills â€” just a single SKILL.md file
- Examples: weekly-report, meeting-notes, pdf-ocr, pdf-compress, mcp-hub, pdf-merge-split, all office manipulation skills
- These are pure "prompt engineering" skills â€” the SKILL.md IS the entire capability
- Size range: 1.1KB - 10.5KB

**Category B: SKILL.md + Scripts**
- ~25% of skills â€” SKILL.md with executable code in `scripts/`
- Examples: chart-image (Node.js), openinsider (Python), apewisdom (Python), aliyun-search (Python), clawd-presence (Python)
- Scripts handle data fetching, chart generation, or system interaction

**Category C: SKILL.md + References + Scripts**
- ~15% of skills â€” full-featured with reference docs
- Examples: self-improvement, product-strategist, senior-devops
- Reference docs provide extended knowledge the agent can consult
- Includes example data and framework documentation

**Category D: Multi-component / App Skills**
- ~10% of skills â€” include full applications
- Examples: dashboard (Flask web app), clawd-presence (terminal display), promptify (multi-agent with sub-agents)
- Include source code, templates, static assets

---

## 3. How Skills Define Triggers and Descriptions

### 3.1 The Summary Field
The `summary` field in the skill metadata acts as the **primary trigger mechanism**. It tells the agent WHEN to activate the skill.

**Best practice pattern (from top skills):**
```
"[What it does]. Use when [trigger conditions]. [Requirements/constraints]."
```

**Examples of excellent summaries (trigger-focused):**
- **hass-cli:** "Control Home Assistant devices and automations via hass-cli. **Use when** controlling smart home devices, lights, switches, sensors, climate, media players, or running automations/scripts. **Requires** HASS_SERVER and HASS_TOKEN environment variables."
- **self-improvement:** "Captures learnings, errors, and corrections... **Use when:** (1) A command fails unexpectedly, (2) User corrects Claude, (3) User requests missing capability..."
- **gmail-manager:** "Expert Gmail management assistant via Rube MCP. **Use this when** the user mentions inbox management, email organization, email triage..."
- **promptify:** "Optimize prompts for clarity and effectiveness. **Use when** user says 'improve this prompt', 'optimize my prompt'..."

**Pattern: The "Use when" clause is the trigger.** The agent's skill loader reads summaries to decide which skill to activate.

### 3.2 SKILL.md Structure Pattern
The SKILL.md typically follows this structure:

```markdown
# Skill Name

[Brief description of what the skill does]

## Quick Reference / Overview
[Table or list mapping situations to actions]

## Setup (if needed)
[Installation/configuration steps]

## Usage
[How to use â€” commands, workflows, examples]

## [Domain-specific sections]
[Templates, formats, best practices]
```

**Key sections observed across skills:**
- **Quick Reference** â€” table of "situation â†’ action" mappings (self-improvement)
- **Why This Skill?** â€” justification and alternatives (chart-image)
- **Setup** â€” one-time installation steps
- **Quick Usage** â€” copy-paste ready examples
- **Options** â€” parameter tables with defaults
- **Workflow** â€” step-by-step processes

---

## 4. Configuration Patterns (API Keys, Env Vars)

### 4.1 Environment Variables
Skills that need external APIs document required env vars in the summary or SKILL.md:
- **hass-cli:** Requires `HASS_SERVER` and `HASS_TOKEN` â€” mentioned directly in summary
- **aliyun-search:** Requires Alibaba Cloud API key â€” configured via script parameters
- **gmail-manager:** Uses Rube MCP â€” requires MCP server setup

### 4.2 Free/No-Key APIs (Security-Friendly)
Several skills explicitly use **free APIs requiring no API key:**
- **crypto-gold-monitor:** "å…è´¹APIæ— éœ€Key" (free API, no key needed)
- **apewisdom:** "using the ApeWisdom API (free)"
- **openinsider:** Scrapes public SEC data
- **chart-image:** Pure local processing, no external API

### 4.3 Configuration Location
- **No standard config file format** â€” skills document requirements in SKILL.md
- Some use `skill.json` (dashboard) but this is rare
- Most rely on environment variables or script parameters

---

## 5. How Skills Interface with Clawdbot

### 5.1 Primary Interface: Prompt Context Injection
The main mechanism is **SKILL.md gets loaded into the agent's context**. The agent reads it and follows the instructions. This is the dominant pattern for ~50% of skills.

### 5.2 Script Execution (exec tool)
Skills with `scripts/` directories are invoked via the `exec` tool:
- **chart-image:** `node /data/clawd/skills/chart-image/scripts/chart.mjs --type line --data '...'`
- **openinsider:** `python scripts/fetch_trades.py`
- **apewisdom:** `python scripts/scan_reddit.py`
- **clawd-presence:** `python scripts/display.py`, `python scripts/configure.py`

### 5.3 Sub-Agent Delegation
Advanced skills define sub-agent roles:
- **promptify:** Has `agents/clarifier.md`, `agents/codebase-researcher.md`, `agents/web-researcher.md` â€” routes to specialized sub-agents
- **multiple-personas:** Defines `profiles/` with SOUL.md + PERSONALITY.md + MEMORY.md per persona â€” each acts as a sub-agent

### 5.4 MCP Integration
- **gmail-manager:** "via Rube MCP" â€” uses Model Context Protocol for Gmail
- **office-mcp:** "MCP server for Word, Excel, PowerPoint operations"
- **mcp-hub:** "Access 1200+ AI Agent tools via Model Context Protocol"

### 5.5 Full Application Skills
- **dashboard:** Full Flask web app (app.py + HTML/CSS/JS) â€” runs as standalone service
- **clawd-presence:** Terminal UI display application

### 5.6 self-improvement's Integration Pattern (reference/best practice)
Has a dedicated `references/clawdbot-integration.md` file and `references/hooks-setup.md` â€” showing how to hook into Clawdbot's lifecycle. Uses:
- `scripts/activator.sh` â€” activation logic
- `scripts/error-detector.sh` â€” monitors for errors
- `scripts/extract-skill.sh` â€” extracts learnings from context

---

## 6. Security Patterns

### 6.1 Safe Patterns âœ…
- **SKILL.md-only skills** â€” Pure text/prompt instructions, no executable code, zero risk
- **Free public API skills** â€” No credentials stored (crypto-gold-monitor, apewisdom, openinsider)
- **Local processing skills** â€” chart-image explicitly avoids external APIs
- **SHA-256 hashes** â€” Every file in the registry has a SHA-256 hash for integrity verification
- **Versioning** â€” All skills have immutable versions with changelogs
- **Download counts + stars** â€” Community signals for trust

### 6.2 Potentially Risky Patterns âš ï¸
- **Shell scripts** â€” `setup.sh`, `scripts/*.sh` could execute arbitrary commands
- **Python scripts** â€” `scripts/*.py` have full system access when executed
- **No sandboxing** â€” Skills execute in the same context as the agent
- **dashboard skill:** "No authentication; recommended for local/trusted use only" â€” explicit security caveat
- **Environment variable requirements** â€” Some skills need API tokens that could be exposed

### 6.3 Red Flags to Watch For ðŸš©
- Skills that request broad permissions or many env vars
- Scripts that make network requests to unknown endpoints
- Skills from unknown authors with no stars/downloads
- Skills with `setup.sh` that install packages or modify system config
- Skills that write to paths outside their own directory

### 6.4 Trust Signals
- **GitHub auth** â€” Skill authors are authenticated via GitHub
- **Owner info** â€” Each skill shows the author's GitHub handle and avatar
- **Download/install/star counts** â€” Community validation
- **Version count** â€” Skills with multiple versions suggest active maintenance
- **"duplicate of" markers** â€” Hub flags copied skills (e.g., self-improvement is noted as duplicate of `@pskoett/self-improving-agent`)

---

## 7. What Makes Top Skills Better

### 7.1 Top 3 Analysis

**#1 Self-Improvement (73 downloads, 1â˜…)**
- âœ… Comprehensive SKILL.md (16.6KB) with quick reference table
- âœ… Rich file structure: SKILL.md + assets + references + scripts
- âœ… Templates for immediate use (LEARNINGS.md template)
- âœ… Clawdbot integration guides
- âœ… Clear "when to use" triggers with numbered scenarios
- âœ… Promotion workflow (learnings â†’ AGENTS.md / CLAUDE.md)

**#2 Chart Image (57 downloads, 1â˜…)**
- âœ… Clear "Why This Skill?" section comparing alternatives
- âœ… Practical: solves a real deployment problem (no Puppeteer on Fly.io)
- âœ… Copy-paste ready examples
- âœ… Complete options table with defaults
- âœ… Lightweight: 4 files total, focused scope
- âœ… Active development: 3 versions with meaningful changelogs

**#3 Promptify (56 downloads, 3â˜… â€” HIGHEST RATED)**
- âœ… Multi-agent architecture with specialized sub-agents
- âœ… Commands directory for standalone invocation
- âœ… Clear trigger phrases in summary
- âœ… Active refinement: v3.1.0 focused on "simplicity and brevity"
- âœ… Unique: improves agent capability at meta-level

### 7.2 Common Success Patterns
1. **Clear trigger language** â€” "Use when..." in summary
2. **Practical utility** â€” Solves real problems (charts, email, OCR)
3. **Copy-paste examples** â€” Ready-to-use commands
4. **Focused scope** â€” Does one thing well
5. **Active maintenance** â€” Multiple versions show investment
6. **Reference documentation** â€” Extended knowledge for complex domains
7. **Templates** â€” Provide starting points users can customize

### 7.3 Anti-Patterns (Lower-Ranked Skills)
- **No summary** (dashboard) â€” Makes trigger matching impossible
- **SKILL.md only for complex tasks** â€” Limits capability to prompt-only
- **Generic descriptions** â€” Don't specify WHEN to activate
- **No examples** â€” Harder to understand usage
- **Batch-published** â€” lijie420461340 published 15+ office skills at once, all v1.0.0, suggesting template-generated content

---

## 8. Hub Metadata & Infrastructure

### 8.1 API Structure
```
GET /api/v1/skills                                    â€” List all skills
GET /api/v1/skills/{slug}                             â€” Skill details + owner
GET /api/v1/skills/{slug}/versions/{version}          â€” Version details + file manifest
```

Each skill has:
- `slug` â€” URL-friendly identifier
- `displayName` â€” Human-readable name
- `summary` â€” Description/trigger text
- `tags` â€” Version tags (e.g., `latest`, `office`, `pdf`, `devops`)
- `stats` â€” downloads, installs (current/allTime), stars, comments, versions
- `owner` â€” GitHub handle, userId, displayName, avatar

### 8.2 File Manifest
Each version lists files with:
- `path` â€” Relative file path within skill
- `size` â€” File size in bytes
- `sha256` â€” Content hash for integrity
- `contentType` â€” MIME type

### 8.3 Download
Skills are downloaded as zip files from:
```
https://auth.clawdhub.com/api/v1/download?slug={slug}
```

### 8.4 Platform Notes
- Hub is **open source** (MIT license): https://github.com/moltbot/molthub
- Built by Peter Steinberger (steipete.me)
- Auth via GitHub OAuth
- The platform is actually called "MoltHub" â€” "ClawdHub" is a deployment/brand name
- Skills support sorting by: Newest, Recently updated, Downloads, Installs, Stars, Name

---

## 9. Key Takeaways for Building Skills

### Essential Requirements
1. **SKILL.md is everything** â€” This is the minimum viable skill
2. **Summary with "Use when..." triggers** â€” Critical for the agent to know when to activate
3. **SHA-256 hashes** â€” Hub verifies file integrity automatically

### Architecture Decision Tree
```
Is it pure instructions/templates?
  â†’ SKILL.md only (Category A)
Does it need data fetching or processing?
  â†’ Add scripts/ directory (Category B)
Does it need extended domain knowledge?
  â†’ Add references/ directory (Category C)
Does it need a running service or UI?
  â†’ Full app structure with src/ (Category D)
Does it need specialized sub-tasks?
  â†’ Add agents/ directory (Promptify pattern)
```

### Best Practices
- Keep SKILL.md under 10KB for fast context loading
- Use Python or Node.js for scripts (both well-supported)
- Document all env var requirements in the summary
- Provide copy-paste command examples
- Use semantic versioning with meaningful changelogs
- Include a "Why This Skill?" section if alternatives exist
- Add templates in assets/ for user customization
- Reference docs go in references/ â€” keeps SKILL.md focused

### Security Best Practices
- Prefer free/public APIs over credentialed ones
- Document security caveats explicitly (like dashboard does)
- Keep scripts focused â€” avoid broad system access
- Use specific file paths rather than dynamic/user-provided ones
- All files get SHA-256 hashed by the hub â€” leverage this for trust
memory/projects/skill-structure-analysis:
# Skill Structure Analysis

Analyzed 11 skills (1 meta-skill + 10 installed) to understand Clawdbot skill architecture.

## Official Framework (skill-creator)

### Required Structure
```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md              # Required - frontmatter + instructions
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/              # Optional - executable code
â”œâ”€â”€ references/           # Optional - docs loaded on-demand
â””â”€â”€ assets/               # Optional - templates/files for output
```

### SKILL.md Format
- **Frontmatter (YAML)**: Only `name` and `description` required. Description is the PRIMARY trigger mechanism â€” determines when the skill activates. Some skills add `homepage` and `metadata` for Clawdbot-specific features.
- **Body (Markdown)**: Instructions loaded AFTER skill triggers. Should be <500 lines. Use progressive disclosure â€” link to references/ for details.

### Key Principles
1. **Concise is key** â€” context window is shared; only add what the model doesn't know
2. **Progressive disclosure** â€” metadata always loaded (~100 words), body on trigger (<5k words), references on-demand (unlimited)
3. **Degrees of freedom** â€” match specificity to task fragility (scripts for fragile ops, prose for flexible ones)
4. **No extraneous files** â€” no README, CHANGELOG, INSTALLATION_GUIDE, etc.

### Clawdbot-Specific Metadata
Many skills use extended frontmatter:
```yaml
metadata:
  clawdbot:
    emoji: "ðŸŒ¤ï¸"
    requires:
      bins: ["curl"]        # Required binaries
      anyBins: ["spogo", "spotify_player"]  # Any one of these
      env: ["GEMINI_API_KEY"]  # Required env vars
    primaryEnv: "GEMINI_API_KEY"
    install:
      - id: "uv-brew"
        kind: "brew"
        formula: "uv"
        bins: ["uv"]
        label: "Install uv (brew)"
```

### `{baseDir}` Variable
Scripts are referenced using `{baseDir}` placeholder, which resolves to the skill's directory at runtime. Used in: nano-banana-pro, video-frames, veo, self-improvement.

---

## Individual Skill Analysis

### 1. weather (SKILL.md only, ~50 lines)
- **Structure**: Single SKILL.md, no scripts/refs/assets
- **Pattern**: Pure knowledge skill â€” teaches the agent to use existing CLI tools (`curl` + free APIs)
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, homepage, metadata (emoji, requires bins)
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Excellent. Concise, two services (primary + fallback), format codes as quick reference. Perfect for "agent already knows curl, just needs the URL patterns."

### 2. nano-banana-pro (SKILL.md + 1 script, ~30 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `scripts/generate_image.py`
- **Pattern**: Script wrapper â€” SKILL.md is just usage docs for the bundled script
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, homepage, metadata (emoji, requires bins+env, primaryEnv, install)
- **Config**: API key via env var OR `skills."nano-banana-pro".apiKey` in clawdbot.json
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Very good. Minimal SKILL.md with clear Generate/Edit examples. Notes section covers gotchas (timestamps, MEDIA: line, don't read image back).

### 3. notion (SKILL.md only, ~130 lines body)
- **Structure**: Single SKILL.md, no scripts
- **Pattern**: API reference skill â€” teaches curl-based API usage with copy-paste examples
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, homepage, metadata (emoji only)
- **Sections**: Setup â†’ API Basics â†’ Common Operations â†’ Property Types â†’ Key Differences â†’ Notes
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Good. Comprehensive API reference with all common operations. Could benefit from a script for auth token management, but curl examples are clear enough. The "Key Differences in 2025-09-03" section is smart â€” addresses version-specific knowledge the model likely doesn't have.

### 4. video-frames (SKILL.md + 1 script, ~20 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `scripts/frame.sh`
- **Pattern**: Minimal script wrapper â€” almost trivially simple
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, homepage, metadata (emoji, requires bins, install)
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Good for its scope. Two examples cover the main use case. Very lean.

### 5. coding-agent (SKILL.md only, ~200 lines body)
- **Structure**: Single SKILL.md, no scripts
- **Pattern**: Comprehensive procedural guide â€” teaches multi-tool orchestration patterns
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, metadata (emoji, requires anyBins)
- **Sections**: PTY warning â†’ Quick Start â†’ Pattern (workdir+background+pty) â†’ Per-tool sections â†’ Rules â†’ Progress Updates â†’ Auto-Notify â†’ Learnings
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Excellent. Real-world patterns with clear do/don't rules. The âš ï¸ Rules section and PTY emphasis prevent common failures. Learnings section captures tribal knowledge. Longer than ideal but justified by complexity.

### 6. github (SKILL.md only, ~40 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `.clawdhub/origin.json`
- **Pattern**: CLI cheatsheet â€” quick reference for `gh` commands
- **Frontmatter**: name, description (no metadata)
- **Effectiveness**: âš ï¸ Adequate but thin. Most of this is knowledge the model already has. The `--jq` examples add value. Could be more effective with advanced patterns (graphql queries, automation workflows).

### 7. spotify-player (SKILL.md only, ~35 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `.clawdhub/origin.json`
- **Pattern**: Dual-tool cheatsheet with preference ordering
- **Frontmatter**: name, description, homepage, metadata (emoji, requires anyBins, install with tap)
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Good. Clear "preferred vs fallback" pattern. Setup instructions included. Concise.

### 8. veo (SKILL.md + 1 script, ~25 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `scripts/generate_video.py` + `.clawdhub/origin.json`
- **Pattern**: Script wrapper (same pattern as nano-banana-pro)
- **Frontmatter**: name, description (minimal â€” no metadata)
- **Config**: Same env var / clawdbot.json pattern as nano-banana-pro
- **Effectiveness**: âœ… Good. Clean, follows established pattern. Lists all CLI options clearly.

### 9. ringbot (SKILL.md only, ~130 lines body)
- **Structure**: SKILL.md + `.clawdhub/origin.json`
- **Pattern**: Product guide + API reference â€” includes marketing-style content alongside technical usage
- **Frontmatter**: name, description (very detailed trigger list â€” "call", "phone", "dial", "ring", "order pizza", etc.)
- **Sections**: Cost breakdown â†’ Two setup options â†’ Use cases â†’ Making a Call â†’ Example workflow â†’ Tips â†’ Service Management
- **Effectiveness**: âš ï¸ Mixed. The trigger keywords in description are smart. The cost breakdown and use cases are useful context. BUT: lots of marketing content (pricing tables, "Why RingBot?") wastes context tokens. The actual API usage (curl POST) could be more prominent.

### 10. self-improving-agent (SKILL.md + 3 scripts + 3 references + 2 assets, ~350 lines body)
- **Structure**: Full skill with all resource types
  - `scripts/`: activator.sh, error-detector.sh, extract-skill.sh
  - `references/`: examples.md, clawdbot-integration.md, hooks-setup.md
  - `assets/`: SKILL-TEMPLATE.md, LEARNINGS.md
- **Pattern**: Complex workflow skill â€” defines processes, formats, and automation hooks
- **Frontmatter**: name (`self-improvement`), description (comprehensive trigger list with 6 specific scenarios)
- **Sections**: Quick Reference table â†’ Setup â†’ Logging Format (templates) â†’ ID Generation â†’ Resolving â†’ Promoting â†’ Detection Triggers â†’ Priority/Area guides â†’ Hook Integration â†’ Skill Extraction â†’ Multi-Agent Support â†’ Clawdbot Integration
- **Effectiveness**: âš ï¸ Mixed. Very thorough but SKILL.md is too long (~350 lines). The Quick Reference table at top is excellent â€” gives fast lookup. But detailed templates for every entry type could move to references/. The multi-agent and Clawdbot integration sections are quite long and could be split out.

---

## Patterns & Best Practices

### What Makes Skills Effective

| Pattern | Examples | Why It Works |
|---------|----------|-------------|
| Concise body (<50 lines) | weather, video-frames, veo | Minimal context cost, fast to parse |
| Script + thin docs | nano-banana-pro, video-frames, veo | Deterministic execution, agent just needs to know CLI args |
| Clear examples over prose | weather, notion, github | Show don't tell â€” agent can copy/adapt |
| Explicit trigger keywords in description | ringbot, self-improvement | Better skill activation |
| Primary + fallback pattern | weather (wttr.in/Open-Meteo), spotify (spogo/spotify_player) | Resilience |
| Quick reference table at top | self-improvement, coding-agent | Fast lookup for common actions |
| âš ï¸ Warning callouts for gotchas | coding-agent (PTY!), nano-banana-pro (don't read image) | Prevents common failures |

### Common Anti-Patterns

| Anti-Pattern | Example | Fix |
|-------------|---------|-----|
| SKILL.md too long (>200 lines) | self-improvement (~350), coding-agent (~200) | Move details to references/ |
| Marketing/sales content | ringbot (cost tables, "Why RingBot?") | Keep only what agent needs to use the tool |
| Redundant knowledge | github (basic gh commands) | Focus on non-obvious patterns |
| No metadata | github, veo, ringbot | Add emoji, requires, install for Clawdbot features |
| Missing `{baseDir}` | ringbot (hardcoded paths) | Use `{baseDir}` for portability |

### Skill Archetypes

1. **Pure Knowledge** (weather, notion, github, coding-agent): SKILL.md only, teaches existing tools
2. **Script Wrapper** (nano-banana-pro, video-frames, veo): Bundled script + thin usage docs
3. **Workflow Process** (self-improvement): Defines procedures with templates, hooks, and multi-file structure
4. **Product Integration** (ringbot, spotify-player): Connects to external service with setup + API docs

### Configuration Patterns

1. **Env vars** (most common): `GEMINI_API_KEY`, etc.
2. **Clawdbot config**: `skills."skill-name".env.VAR_NAME` in `~/.clawdbot/clawdbot.json`
3. **File-based**: `~/.config/notion/api_key` (notion)
4. **Binary dependencies**: declared in `metadata.clawdbot.requires.bins` / `anyBins`
5. **Auto-install**: `metadata.clawdbot.install` with brew formulas

### File Organization Rules

- Scripts use `{baseDir}/scripts/` path with `{baseDir}` variable
- References are linked from SKILL.md with guidance on when to read them
- Assets are used in output, not loaded into context
- `.clawdhub/origin.json` appears on hub-installed skills (tracking metadata)
- No README, CHANGELOG, or auxiliary docs inside skill folders

# Stanley's Sensor Stack
*"APIs are my sensors. I'm the orchestrator."*

Matt's insight: The iPhone had accelerometer, GPS, ambient light, gyroscope, camera, mic, touch â€” each useless alone, but combined they enabled every app imaginable. Stanley's equivalent is APIs and tools. The more "sensors" connected, the more emergent capabilities.

---

## ðŸ—£ï¸ VOICE & COMMUNICATION

| Sensor | What It Gives Me | Example |
|--------|-----------------|---------|
| **ElevenLabs** | My own voice â€” clone or custom. Can speak, narrate, tell stories | Voice memos, morning briefings as audio, storytime |
| **Twilio** | Phone calls + SMS. I can call people, receive calls, send texts | Call the IRS for Matt, appointment confirmations, 2FA codes |
| **SendBlue / iMessage API** | iMessage from my own number | Text Amy "Matt's running late", coordinate with friends |
| **Telegram Bot API** | Already have this âœ… | Current primary channel |

**Emergent combo:** ElevenLabs + Twilio = I can *call someone and talk to them in my own voice*. That's wild.

## ðŸ§  INTELLIGENCE & MODELS

## ðŸ”§ CREATION & OUTPUT

**Emergent combo:** Image gen + voice + video = I can create a full product ad for WP. Lifestyle photo, voiceover, and short-form video â€” all while Matt sleeps.

---

## ðŸ  HOME & IoT

| **Tesla API** | Car status, climate, location | Pre-heat the Lambo (if it had Tesla's API lol) |
| **Ring / Doorbell API** | Front door monitoring | "Someone's at the door" |
| **Sonos / HomePod** | Play music, announcements | Morning briefing on speakers |

## ðŸ” SECURITY & AUTH

| **Cloudflare** | DNS, security, tunnels | Expose local services safely |

## THE POWER IS IN COMBINATIONS

Just like the iPhone â€” no one predicted Uber from "GPS + cellular + touch screen." The emergent capabilities come from connecting sensors in ways we haven't imagined yet.

Recovery's solid, weather's perfect for a ride before your 2pm call. WP did $1,200 yesterday. Bitcoin touched $98K overnight. One email from Patrick worth reading. Your IRS call is overdue â€” want me to dial them?"

That's not a chatbot. That's a chief of staff.

memory/projects/starlink-mini-tesla.md:
# Starlink Mini in Tesla Model 3 â€” Mobile Command Center

## Starlink Mini Specs
- **Size:** Compact, fits in a backpack
- **Power:** DC power input, ~25-40W typical draw
- **WiFi:** Built-in router
- **Speed:** Max download over 200 Mbps
- **In-motion:** Officially supported on all Roam plans
- **Works at 60mph** â€” confirmed by Reddit users through rear window

## Plan Options (Starlink Roam)
| Plan | Data | Cost |
|------|------|------|
| Roam 100GB | 100 GB/month | $50/mo |
| Roam Unlimited | Unlimited | $165/mo |
- **Standby Mode:** Pause anytime (small monthly fee), reactivate instantly
- **30-day trial** with full refund
- **In-motion use** supported on all plans
- **Hardware cost:** ~$599 for Mini kit

**Recommendation:** Start with Roam 100GB ($50/mo). Upgrade to Unlimited if you're using it as a daily driver command center.

## Power â€” The Key Question

**Tesla Model 3 USB ports: NOT enough**
- USB-A ports: 5V/2.4A = ~12W max
- USB-C ports: 5V/3A = ~15W max  
- Starlink Mini draws 25-40W â€” USB can't handle it

**Solutions (from r/Starlink):**
1. **12V outlet/cigarette lighter adapter** â€” Easiest. Starlink Mini has DC input. Get a 12V DC to DC adapter (the Mini runs on 12V-48V DC). Plug into the Tesla 12V socket in the center console.
2. **Hardwire to 12V battery** â€” More permanent. Wire directly to the low-voltage battery with an inline fuse. Several Reddit users have done this successfully.
3. **USB-C PD adapter** â€” Some users report success with a 45W USB-C PD adapter, but this is unreliable and risks brownouts.

**Best approach:** 12V socket with a proper DC adapter. Clean, reversible, no mods needed.

## Mounting Options

### Inside the car (easiest for Model 3)
- **Rear parcel shelf** (behind back seats) â€” Most popular. Lay flat facing up through the glass roof/rear window. Works at 60mph confirmed.
- **Dashboard** â€” Works but obstructs view
- **Suction cup on rear window** â€” Some users do this

### Outside (better signal but more complex)
- **Magnetic mount on roof** â€” Works on steel roofs, but Model 3 has aluminum + glass roof (magnets won't stick to glass)
- **Roof rack mount** â€” Needs a rack first
- **One guy's fell off at 80mph, got run over, and still worked** ðŸ˜‚

**Recommendation for Model 3:** Rear parcel shelf, flat, facing up through the rear glass. Simple, hidden, no mods. Glass is transparent to satellite signals.

## Heat Management
- San Diego summer interior can hit 150Â°F+ when parked
- Starlink Mini rated for operating temps up to ~122Â°F (50Â°C)
- **Tesla Cabin Overheat Protection** helps â€” keeps interior below 105Â°F when enabled
- **Camp Mode** keeps HVAC running and would keep the Mini cool
- For parked operation: use Camp Mode or Dog Mode

## Does It Work While Driving?
**Yes.** In-motion use is officially supported. Reddit users confirm stable connections at highway speeds (60-80mph). The Mini handles handoffs between satellites well.

## Real-World Reddit Threads
- "I wired my Starlink Mini to my car" â€” full install guide
- "Not bad for a Mini through the rear window of a car at 60mph" â€” speed test proof
- "Ways to Power the Mini in a Car" â€” power discussion
- "Mini fell off car on highway @80mph, got ran over, and still works!" â€” durability lol
- "Car solution to Starlink mini" â€” mounting solutions

## vs Alternatives
| Option | Speed | Monthly | Notes |
|--------|-------|---------|-------|
| Starlink Mini | 200+ Mbps | $50-165 | Best speed, works everywhere |
| Tesla Premium Connectivity | ~5 Mbps | $10/mo | Already in the car, but slow |
| T-Mobile 5G hotspot | 50-300 Mbps | $50/mo | Good in cities, dead in rural |
| Phone hotspot | Varies | Free-ish | Drains phone, data caps |

**Verdict:** If you want a true always-connected command center that works everywhere (mountains, desert, highway), Starlink Mini is the move. T-Mobile is cheaper in the city but useless on remote rides.

## Shopping List
1. **Starlink Mini Kit** â€” ~$599 (starlink.com/roam)
2. **12V DC adapter cable** for Starlink Mini â€” ~$20-30
3. **Non-slip mat** for rear parcel shelf â€” ~$10
4. **Roam plan** â€” $50/mo (100GB) to start

**Total upfront:** ~$630
**Monthly:** $50

## 1.2 â€” Pick Your Interface Pattern

| # | Pattern | When To Use | Frequency | Example |
|---|---------|-------------|-----------|---------|
| 1 | **CLI Wrapper** | External binary on PATH | ~70% | github, apple-reminders, imsg |
| 2 | **Script Runner** | Bundled Python/Shell/Node script | ~15% | nano-banana-pro, openai-image-gen |
| 3 | **API Integration** | Direct curl to external API | ~5% | notion |
| 4 | **Native Bridge** | macOS-specific via AppleScript/frameworks | ~3% | apple-notes (memo), bear-notes |
| 5 | **Built-in Tool Teaching** | Teaches Clawdbot's own tools (browser, canvas, nodes) | ~3% | canvas, discord |
| 6 | **Agent Orchestrator** | Spawns/manages sub-agents | ~2% | coding-agent, oracle |
| 7 | **MCP Integration** | Uses Model Context Protocol server | ~2% | gmail-manager, office-mcp |

### Decision Tree

```
What does your skill wrap?
â”œâ”€â”€ An installed CLI tool (gh, remindctl, openhue)?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 1: CLI Wrapper
â”œâ”€â”€ A script you wrote (Python, Shell, Node)?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 2: Script Runner
â”œâ”€â”€ A REST API called via curl?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 3: API Integration
â”œâ”€â”€ A macOS-native app (Notes, Calendar, Photos)?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 4: Native Bridge
â”œâ”€â”€ A Clawdbot built-in tool (browser, canvas, message)?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 5: Built-in Tool Teaching
â”œâ”€â”€ Another AI agent (Codex, Claude Code)?
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 6: Agent Orchestrator
â””â”€â”€ An MCP server?
    â””â”€â”€ â†’ Pattern 7: MCP Integration
```

## 1.3 â€” Copy-Paste Templates

# my-tool

Use `my-tool` to [what it does].

## Setup

- Auth (if needed): `my-tool auth`

## Common Commands

### Read
- List all: `my-tool list --json`
- Get one: `my-tool get <id> --json`
- Search: `my-tool search "query" --json`

### Write
- Create: `my-tool create --name "Name" --flag value`
- Update: `my-tool update <id> --field "new value"`
- Delete: `my-tool delete <id>` *(confirm with user first)*

## Output
Always use `--json` for structured output. Pipe through `jq` when needed.

## Notes
- [Important quirk or limitation]
- [Platform/permission requirement]
```

## API Key

- Or config: `skills."my-script".apiKey` in `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`

# my-api

## Setup
1. Get API key: https://service.com/settings
2. Config: set `skills."my-api".apiKey` in `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`

## API Requests

### List Items
```bash
curl -s "https://api.service.com/v1/items" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer ${SERVICE_API_KEY}" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" | jq '.items[]'
```

### Create Item
```bash
curl -s -X POST "https://api.service.com/v1/items" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer ${SERVICE_API_KEY}" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "...", "type": "..."}'
```

## Notes
- Rate limit: ~X req/sec
- All responses are JSON
```

# Agent Tool

Use `[agent]` for [purpose].

## âš ï¸ CRITICAL: Always use PTY mode
```bash
exec({ command: "agent-tool --args", pty: true, background: true })
```

## Launch Pattern
1. Set working directory
2. Launch with `pty: true, background: true`
3. Poll with `process.log` every 10-30 seconds
4. Write input with `process.write` when needed
5. Kill with `process.kill` when done

## Rules
- Never run without `pty: true`
- Always background long-running agents
- Poll, don't block
- Kill zombie sessions
